Les dispositions attaquées imposent aux autorités administratives de fixer, sur la base d un modèle établi par le Roi, un plan des prestations à effectuer et les mesures à prendre par les membres du personnel durant la grève  article 19 , afin que les droits fondamentaux définis à l article 17 de la loi  que l article 18 complète  soient garantis pendant cette même période. Ces dispositions fixent donc le   service minimum   qui doit être fourni pour que les   services essentiels   soient assurés pendant la durée de la grève. Si la partie requérante ne conteste pas l objectif qui consiste à garantir le respect des droits fondamentaux des détenus en cas de grève des membres du personnel pénitentiaire, elle estime cependant que le   service minimum  , tel qu il est conçu par la loi attaquée, est totalement détaché de la réalité de la vie pénitentiaire. Les activités   essentielles   définies aux articles 17 et 18 de la loi attaquée recouvrent en effet la majeure partie des activités habituelles de l administration pénitentiaire, pour lesquelles le nombre de membres du personnel pénitentiaire est déjà insuffisant en temps normal. Le modèle visé aux articles 19 et 20 de la loi attaquée, qui doit permettre d assurer l ensemble des services essentiels ainsi énumérés, est donc pensé et organisé uniquement pour les grèves de longue durée, qui sont très rares dans un établissement pénitentiaire, et il ne tient aucunement compte des nécessités du service qui peuvent varier selon les jours de grève concernés, du parcours des détenus ou du nombre de jours de grève annoncés. Pour assurer ces services, plus de la moitié des membres du personnel devront être présents pendant une journée de grève, de sorte que la loi attaquée fige au maximum le nombre d agents nécessaires pour assurer ces services essentiels, quelle que soit la durée de la grève. Cette restriction de la liberté d association, de la liberté syndicale et du droit de grève est d autant plus disproportionnée qu à partir du troisième jour de grève, des agents qui ont déclaré participer au mouvement de grève pourront être réquisitionnés et que cette réquisition pourrait en outre, à l issue de l évaluation du système qui doit avoir lieu au plus tard un an après l entrée en vigueur de la loi, être étendue et mise en œuvre dès le premier jour de grève. A.10.5. La quatrième branche du moyen porte sur la réquisition. Les dispositions attaquées permettent au gouverneur de province ou au ministre-président de la Région de Bruxelles-Capitale, ou à leurs délégués, d établir un dispositif en vue d atteindre un taux de présence de membres du personnel qui permette de garantir les services définis dans le plan évoqué plus haut et, le cas échéant, de donner ordre aux membres du personnel de se rendre sur leur lieu de travail, afin d y effectuer les prestations qui sont garanties aux détenus. Cette possibilité de réquisitionner des agents existe dès que la grève est annoncée pour plus de deux jours et, à l issue de l évaluation de la loi qui doit être réalisée au terme de la première année de son entrée en vigueur, conformément à son article 20, cette possibilité pourrait être étendue à toute journée de grève. Comme l a souligné la section de législation du Conseil d État, ce pouvoir de réquisition constitue une restriction du droit de grève, et cette restriction est d autant plus importante qu au regard des services essentiels établis dans un plan préalable, fixe et général, et du nombre d agents largement inférieur aux nécessités du service, plus de la moitié des membres du personnel devront être présents chaque jour de grève. Il en découle que le pouvoir de réquisition devra nécessairement et systématiquement être mis en œuvre pour atteindre ce taux, alors même que celui-ci ne correspond pas aux nécessités réelles du service. Une telle réquisition constitue une atteinte disproportionnée à la liberté syndicale et au droit à la concertation collective, dès lors qu elle est de nature à anéantir le rapport de forces dont les organisations syndicales doivent pouvoir disposer pour pouvoir soutenir leurs revendications dans le cadre d un conflit social. A.11.1. Le Conseil des ministres rappelle tout d abord que le droit de grève n est pas absolu et qu il peut faire l objet de limitations justifiées par l objectif légitime qui consiste à améliorer le fonctionnement général des établissements pénitentiaires, à condition de ménager un équilibre entre le droit de grève des agents pénitentiaires et la garantie de conditions de vie conformes au droit des détenus à ne pas subir des traitements inhumains ou dégradants durant leur détention, et de mettre fin aux réquisitions systématiques des services de police et des services civils, qui ne peuvent alors plus assurer leurs missions d intérêt général pendant la grève. A.11.2. En ce qui concerne les première et troisième branches du moyen, qui portent sur des mesures qui sont liées, le Conseil des ministres souligne que le modèle de plan opérationnel a été adopté par un arrêté royal du 4 août 2019 et que le ministre adoptera des plans opérationnels pour chaque établissement pénitentiaire afin que les services essentiels soient garantis aux détenus. L obligation de déclaration tend dès lors à permettre au chef d établissement de connaître, au moins dix jours avant la grève, le nombre de personnes qui travailleront durant la grève, afin qu il puisse vérifier si le plan opérationnel est satisfaisant ou non. Ce délai raisonnable est donc indispensable pour permettre au chef d établissement de savoir, le cas échéant, s il doit trouver une solution pour assurer les services essentiels à l égard des détenus. La section de législation du Conseil d État a d ailleurs considéré que le délai de dix jours et celui de 72 heures n étaient pas déraisonnables. Le Conseil des ministres estime que la partie requérante ne démontre pas en quoi ces délais constitueraient une restriction déraisonnable du droit de grève. Selon le Conseil des ministres, les effets néfastes invoqués par la partie requérante ne pourraient se produire que si le chef d établissement violait l article 16 même de la loi attaquée, en cherchant à intimider ou à dissuader de potentiels grévistes. A.11.3. En ce qui concerne la deuxième branche du moyen, le Conseil des ministres souligne qu en réponse à une observation de la section de législation du Conseil d État, le texte a été modifié de manière à préciser que la mesure administrative ne peut consister en une sanction disciplinaire. En outre, la critique est prématurée, puisque la loi attaquée ne fait que prévoir la possibilité de principe d infliger des mesures administratives et que l arrêté royal qui fixera ces mesures pourra faire l objet d une contestation. Enfin, il n est pas déraisonnable de prévoir d infliger une mesure administrative pour sanctionner le non-respect de la loi attaquée, dès lors qu une éventuelle mesure administrative ne peut en aucune manière être utilisée pour stigmatiser un agent. A.11.4. En ce qui concerne la quatrième branche du moyen, le Conseil des ministres estime que les services essentiels visés à l article 17 de la loi attaquée constituent une charge de travail bien différente pour les agents concernés, selon qu ils travaillent dans le cadre du service minimum ou dans le cadre de l exercice normal de leurs fonctions. Les critiques concernant le manque général d effectifs dans les prisons sont par ailleurs étrangères à la loi attaquée et ne sauraient justifier que les conditions de détention portent atteinte aux droits fondamentaux des détenus. Par ailleurs, le législateur a fait preuve d une certaine flexibilité en adoptant la loi attaquée, puisqu il a organisé un plan opérationnel par prison devant être soumis au comité de concertation de base. Enfin, si la loi ne permettait pas de réquisitionner des membres du personnel pour assurer le service minimum à l égard des détenus, elle serait dénuée de toute utilité. Un mécanisme de réquisition des services de police et de la protection civile existait d ailleurs avant la loi attaquée, mais il ne constituait pas une solution adéquate. Par ailleurs, cette possibilité de réquisition ne concerne que les grèves d une durée supérieure à 24 heures, de sorte que le législateur a choisi la voie qui affecte le moins le droit de grève par rapport à l objectif poursuivi. A.12.1. En ce qui concerne les première et troisième branches du moyen, la partie requérante répond qu en se focalisant sur les deux délais fixés dans la loi, le Conseil des ministres élude totalement la portée des deux branches et qu il ne répond aucunement aux critiques dirigées contre la troisième branche, que la partie requérante demande d examiner distinctement. La déclaration que les agents pénitentiaires doivent faire au plus tard 72 heures avant l issue du préavis de grève empêche ceux-ci de s inscrire en toute liberté dans le mouvement social et engendre un déséquilibre manifeste entre les interlocuteurs sociaux, surtout en cas de grève de longue durée. La partie requérante évoque ici non pas la théorie, mais la réalité des rapports de forces dans le déroulement d une négociation collective. En outre, même si les déclarations sont détruites, les directions ont accès aux documents administratifs qui leur permettent d identifier les agents qui ont participé à la grève et de les intimider, le cas échéant. A.12.2. En ce qui concerne la deuxième branche du moyen, la partie requérante répond que, si la mesure administrative attaquée n est pas une sanction disciplinaire au sens du statut des agents de l État, elle constitue néanmoins une mesure répressive et, à ce titre, une sanction. En application de la loi attaquée, le Roi a adopté l arrêté royal du 19 novembre 2019   portant exécution des articles 15 et 16 de la loi du 23 mars 2019 concernant l organisation des services pénitentiaires et le statut du personnel pénitentiaire  , en vertu duquel la mesure administrative a des conséquences immédiates sur l ancienneté administrative de l agent et sur sa situation pécuniaire. Indépendamment du recours que la partie requérante va introduire contre cet arrêté royal, le principe même d infliger une mesure administrative est prévu par la loi attaquée, et c est ce principe que la partie requérante conteste dans le cadre du recours présentement examiné. A.12.3. En ce qui concerne la quatrième branche du moyen, la partie requérante répond que la liste des mesures visées à l article 17 énumère la majeure partie des activités de l administration pénitentiaire. Or, alors même que certains de ces services ne doivent être fournis qu une fois par semaine, cette liste suppose, lorsqu il s agit de déterminer le nombre d agents nécessaires en cas de grève, que ces services soient accomplis tous les jours. Le Conseil des ministres ne conteste d ailleurs pas qu eu égard au régime qui est fixé, plus de la moitié des membres du personnel devront être présents pour effectuer les services ainsi énumérés. Ce pourcentage de 50  , associé à la situation de sous-effectif chronique qui avoisine les 80   des effectifs nécessaires, a pour effet de restreindre fortement l accès au droit de grève, de mettre à mal la liberté syndicale et d ouvrir la voie à des réquisitions systématiques. En outre, chaque établissement pénitentiaire sera lié par le modèle de plan opérationnel prescrit par la loi attaquée et figé dans l arrêté royal du 4 août 2019   portant exécution de l article 19 de la loi du 23 mars 2019 concernant l organisation des services pénitentiaires et le statut du personnel pénitentiaire  . L établissement ne pourra donc qu indiquer le nombre de membres du personnel nécessaire en cas de grève pour faire assurer les services énumérés, sans que le chef d établissement puisse revoir cette organisation en vue de garantir le respect des droits fondamentaux des détenus en fonction de la durée de la grève annoncée. Cette mesure est par ailleurs de nature à renforcer le caractère systématique et absolu des réquisitions possibles, afin que le taux de présence fixé de manière générale et préalable soit atteint. La réquisition prévue par la loi attaquée est d autant moins nécessaire que, comme ils l ont fait depuis toujours, les services de police et de sécurité civile peuvent assurer la sécurité dans les prisons et répondre aux besoins des détenus dans le cas exceptionnel d une grève qui perdure. A.13. Le Conseil des ministres réplique que la loi attaquée devait nécessairement fixer un délai de rigueur pour la déclaration de participation à la grève, sous peine de vider de sa substance le but, poursuivi par le législateur, de garantir le respect des droits fondamentaux des détenus. Les délais différents selon que l agent décide finalement de travailler ou de faire grève sont raisonnables et s expliquent par le fait qu il est moins perturbant pour l organisation d avoir trop d effectifs que trop peu. La mesure administrative critiquée a pour seul but de faire respecter ces délais et elle ne constitue pas une mesure disciplinaire. La critique formulée par la partie requérante en ce qui concerne la possibilité d identifier les grévistes ne concerne pas la loi attaquée, dès lors que cette possibilité existait déjà avant l adoption de la loi attaquée, étant donné que les grévistes doivent nécessairement se signaler car leur participation à une grève a des répercussions sur leur traitement. Au contraire, la loi attaquée offre plus de garanties, puisqu elle prévoit que les données seront détruites au terme du conflit social. Le Conseil des ministres n est pas en mesure de contester les pourcentages avancés par la partie requérante, puisque ceux-ci dépendront de chaque prison et du plan organisationnel adopté. Les droits des détenus doivent par ailleurs être assurés, quelle que soit la durée de la grève, et l organisation du tableau de service   qui devra évidemment respecter le plan opérationnel   sera modulable par le chef d établissement. Enfin, les réquisitions des services de la police et de la protection civile demeurent possibles si le mécanisme mis en place par la loi attaquée ne permet pas de maintenir l ordre dans un établissement pénitentiaire.   B   Quant aux dispositions attaquées et leur contexte B.1. La partie requérante sollicite l annulation de la loi du 23 mars 2019   concernant l organisation des services pénitentiaires et le statut du personnel pénitentiaire    ci-après   la loi du 23 mars 2019 . B.2.1. Autour de quatre principes fondamentaux que sont   la continuité, la qualité, l engagement et la responsabilisation  , la loi du 23 mars 2019   vise à instaurer ce cadre législatif afin de répondre à ce déficit de légalité  , et   plus principalement à mettre en place les mécanismes de nature à asseoir la légitimité de l institution pénitentiaire et à favoriser, ce faisant, l adhésion de tous les membres du personnel à sa mission    Doc. parl., Chambre, 2018-2019, DOC 54-3351 001, p. 9      L administration pénitentiaire est un maillon de la chaîne pénale. En tant que tel, elle joue un rôle non négligeable dans la sécurité que l État doit garantir aux citoyens. S agissant de l administration pénitentiaire, la sécurité s entend à la fois au sens statique du terme, à savoir le maintien en lieu de sûreté des personnes dont la justice a estimé qu elles devaient être maintenues en lieu de sûreté, mais aussi sécurité dynamique, qui tient compte du fait que ces personnes retourneront à un moment donné dans la société libre. L emprisonnement porte, par nature, atteinte à un droit fondamental, à savoir le droit à la liberté individuelle. Il n est pas concevable, dans une société démocratique, que le législateur ne se prononce pas sur la manière dont l institution doit être organisée et fonctionner. L enjeu sociétal que représente la prison appelle une réflexion au plus haut niveau de manière à préciser sa mission, ses objectifs prioritaires, ses valeurs, en tenant compte de ce qui est attendu d elle et l obligation de couler cette réflexion dans un texte de loi    ibid., p. 7 . B.2.2. L article 4 de la loi du 23 mars 2019 définit les missions de l administration pénitentiaire comme suit       1er. L administration pénitentiaire a pour mission d assurer, dans le respect des lois et réglementations en vigueur, l exécution des peines et mesures privatives de liberté. Dans ce contexte, elle garantit et promeut, quelles que soient les circonstances, l exercice effectif des droits des détenus et des droits des membres de son personnel.   2. Les services prestés par les membres du personnel de l administration pénitentiaire au sein des prisons sont considérés comme étant des services essentiels, au sens des dispositions contenues dans   La Liberté syndicale. Compilation des décisions du Comité de la liberté syndicale   du Bureau International du Travail de 2018 et plus précisément les dispositions n  830 et n  836.      . B.2.3. En ce qui concerne le statut du personnel pénitentiaire, les travaux préparatoires constatent que   les missions, tâches, droits et devoirs du personnel pénitentiaire doivent eux aussi bénéficier d un ancrage légal qui s articule de manière cohérente avec les dispositions réglant le statut des détenus    Doc. parl., Chambre, 2018-2019, DOC 54-3351 001, p. 7 . Par ailleurs, la loi du 23 mars 2019 met en œuvre un autre principe qui est celui   d assurer en toute circonstance l exercice des missions de l administration pénitentiaire  , l accord de gouvernement fédéral de 2014 ayant   retenu explicitement l objectif d instaurer dans les prisons un service garanti pendant les périodes de grèves    ibid., p. 13 . La loi du 23 mars 2019 instaure dès lors, pendant les périodes de grève,   des mécanismes qui assurent l exercice des missions de l institution pénitentiaire de manière continue    ibid., p. 14 . L avant-projet de loi devenu la loi du 23 mars 2019 a fait l objet de négociations avec les syndicats représentatifs  ibid., p. 10; voy. aussi Doc. parl., Chambre, 2018-2019, DOC 54-3351 004, pp. 4-5 . B.2.4. L article 37 de la loi du 23 mars 2019 dispose     À l exception du présent article, qui entre en vigueur le jour de la publication de la présente loi au Moniteur Belge et les articles 4, 12, 15 à 20, 32, 34 et 36 qui entrent en vigueur le 1er juillet 2019, le Roi détermine la date à laquelle chaque article de la présente loi entre en vigueur  . Quant à l étendue du recours B.3. La Cour détermine l objet du recours en annulation à partir du contenu de la requête et, en particulier, en tenant compte de l exposé des moyens. Elle n examine que les dispositions attaquées contre lesquelles un moyen est dirigé. B.4. Les moyens développés dans la requête ne sont dirigés que contre les articles 3, 7, 9, 10 et 15 à 35 de la loi du 23 mars 2019. La Cour limite dès lors son examen à ces dispositions. Quant au fond En ce qui concerne le premier moyen B.5. Le premier moyen est pris de la violation des articles 10 et 11, lus en combinaison avec les articles 37 et 107, de la Constitution, ainsi que du principe de la séparation des pouvoirs et du principe de la motivation matérielle des actes législatifs. La partie requérante estime qu en fixant un statut complet et autonome du personnel de l administration pénitentiaire, la loi du 23 mars 2019 empiète sur une compétence exclusive du Roi et crée une discrimination, en ce qui concerne les conditions d emploi, entre les membres du personnel pénitentiaire et les membres du personnel de la fonction publique fédérale. Elle critique plus particulièrement la pertinence et la justification des mesures prévues dans les articles 7, 9, 10, 21, 22, 25, 26, 29, 30 et 34 de la loi du 23 mars 2019. La partie requérante critique également le fait que l ensemble de ces mesures sont applicables à l ensemble du personnel pénitentiaire, en contact ou non avec les détenus. B.6.1. L article 37 de la Constitution dispose     Au Roi appartient le pouvoir exécutif fédéral, tel qu il est réglé par la Constitution  . L article 107 de la Constitution dispose     Le Roi confère les grades dans l armée. Il nomme aux emplois d administration générale et de relation extérieure, sauf les exceptions établies par les lois. Il ne nomme à d autres emplois qu en vertu de la disposition expresse d une loi  . B.6.2. Les articles 37 et 107, alinéa 2, de la Constitution réservent au Roi la compétence de principe pour régler le statut des fonctionnaires de l administration générale. B.7.1. En ce qui concerne le statut du personnel pénitentiaire, les travaux préparatoires exposent que le titre IV de la loi du 23 mars 2019 vise à rassembler de manière cohérente les réglementations existantes     Le statut des personnels pénitentiaires et leurs règles de fonctionnement doivent être déduits d un ensemble disparate de dispositions diverses parfois très   datées    il s agit notamment de l arrêté royal du 21 mai 1965 portant Règlement général des établissements pénitentiaires, l arrêté royal du 14 mai 1971 portant instructions spéciales applicables aux agents des services extérieurs de l Administration des établissements pénitentiaires et l arrêté ministériel du 12 juillet 1971 portant Instructions générales pour les établissements pénitentiaires . sections.full_text: Identification  SRB-2015-3-004 Už-1696 2013 11.06.2015 The Republic of Serbia THE CONSTITUTIONAL COURT No. Už-1696 2013 __________ 2015 Belgrade The Grand Chamber of the Constitutional Court, composed of  President of the court and Chamber president, Vesna Iliæ Preliæ, and the judges Dr. Bosa Nenandiæ, Katarina Manojloviæ Andriæ, Dr. Olivera Vuèiæ, Predrag Æetkoviæ, Milan Staniæ, Bratislav Djokiæ, and Tomislav Stojkoviæ, LLM, Chamber members, in proceedings on the constitutional appeal filed by  Office Support  Ltd., pursuant to Article 167 4 in relation to Article 170 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, at the Chamber session held on 11 June 2015, made the following DECISION 1. The constitutional appeal filed by O.S. Ltd. is upheld, having been established that the appellant s right to a fair trial, guaranteed under Article 32 1 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, has been violated by the Belgrade Commercial Court s ruling no. IPV  Iv . 1124 12 of 25 December 2012, while in its remaining part the constitutional appeal is dismissed. 2. The Belgrade Commercial Court ruling no. IPV  Iv . 1124 12, of 25 December 2012, is cancelled, and the court is ordered to re-decide the complaint filed by the appellant against the Belgrade Commercial Court ruling no. Iv. 17138 12, of 26 November 2012. Reasoning 1. On 28 February 2013,  O.S.  Ltd., Belgrade, filed a constitutional appeal with the Constitutional Court against the Belgrade Commercial Court ruling no. IPV  Iv . 1124 12 of 25 December 2012, alleging a violation of the right to a fair trial guaranteed under Article 32 1 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, and the right to equal protection guaranteed under Article 36 1 of the Constitution. The filer of the constitutional appeal  hereinafter   the appellant  , in its constitutional appeal, among other things, alleges  that its enforcement motion based on an authentic document, filed by the appellant in the capacity of an enforcement creditor, has been dismissed as incomplete by the first-instance ruling, due to its alleged omission to specify whether the enforcement was to be conducted by a court or an enforcement officer; that the enforcement court has incompletely established the relevant circumstances for this legal matter and erroneously applied material and procedural law to the appellant's detriment; that, when ruling on the complaint, the chamber of the first-instance court upheld the ruling by which the enforcement motion was dismissed as incomplete; that, in the disputed ruling, the reasons in support of the decision were not stated in a sufficiently precise manner; that the court did not, to a sufficient extent, establish nor support the key arguments for making the ruling to the detriment of the enforcement creditor, which is one of the integral elements of the right under Article 32 1 of the Constitution; that the reasoning and the reasons offered in support of the disputed ruling, are in contradiction with the enactment terms; that in its complaint the appellant pointed out that in the enforcement motion it had been indicated that  the Belgrade Commercial Court, subsequent to conducting proceedings and presentation of evidence, was to make and enforce the following enforcement ruling , from which it could be clearly established that the enforcement creditor, already in the enforcement motion, specified that in this matter the enforcement was to be conducted by the court; that the chamber of the first-instance court found that the enforcement creditor s allegation that the manner of conducting enforcement had been specified in the motion by an indication of the court as the enforcement agent, could not result in a different court decision, as such allegation could not be considered specific as to who was to conduct the enforcement, i.e. the court or an enforcement officer, and that its right under Article 36 1 of the Constitution has been violated, as the same court, when the appellant filed enforcement motions with identical content in other cases of enforcement, rightfully considered them as complete enforcement motions. The appellant proposes that the Constitutional Court uphold the constitutional appeal, and it has also submitted a claim for compensation of pecuniary damage. 2. Pursuant to Article 170 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, a constitutional appeal may be filed against individual acts or actions of government bodies or organisations entrusted with public powers, by which human or minority rights and freedoms guaranteed by the Constitution have been violated or withheld, if other legal remedies for their protection have been exhausted, or have not been envisaged. In the proceedings of providing constitutional protection, when examining whether a constitutional appeal may be considered grounded within the limits of the stated claim, the Constitutional Court establishes whether in the decision making process regarding the rights and duties of an appellant, his constitutionally guaranteed right or freedom has been violated or withheld. 3. In the conducted preliminary proceedings, the Constitutional Court has established, having inspected the submitted documentation, the following facts and circumstances of relevance for making the decision  On 21 November 2012, the enforcement creditor, here the appellant, filed through his authorised representative an enforcement motion based on an authentic document with the Belgrade Commercial Court, against an enforcement debtor, K.S, Belgrade, for the purpose of settling a monetary claim equalling 202,883.59 rsd of the principle debt, with a legally established default interest rate and enforcement proceedings costs. In the enforcement motion it has been stated, among other things, that  the enforcement debtor proposes that the Belgrade Commercial Court, following conducted proceedings and presentation of evidence, make an enforcement ruling and enforce the following...  By its ruling no. Iv. 17138 12 of 26 November 2012, the Belgrade Commercial Court dismissed as incomplete the enforcement motion, due to the enforcement creditor not having specified whether the enforcement was to be conducted by the court or an enforcement officer. When deciding the enforcement creditor's complaint, the Belgrade Commercial Court, by its disputed ruling no. IPV  Iv . 1124 12 of 25 December 2012, rejected the enforcement creditor's complaint and upheld the first-instance ruling. From the reasoning of the disputed ruling, it follows  that the first-instance court made the disputed ruling correctly applying Article 35 6 of the Law on Enforcement and Security, which regulates that in an enforcement motion, the enforcement creditor is obliged to indicate whether enforcement proceedings are to be conducted by the court or an enforcement officer; that the enforcement creditor is obliged to indicate already in the enforcement motion the manner in which, in the concrete case, the enforcement shall be conducted for the purpose of settling the claim in question; that, as the enforcement creditor did not comply with the stated requirement, and in light of the fact that the enforcement creditor was represented by an authorised representative who is a lawyer, the chamber held that it had been correctly established in the disputed ruling that the enforcement creditor s enforcement motion of the of 21 November 2012 did not contain everything necessary to enable acting on it and that the enforcement creditor s allegations, that the manner of enforcement had been stated as it had been indicated in the motion that the ruling was to be enforced by the court, could not result in a different decision, as such allegation could not be considered specific regarding who was to conduct the enforcement, i.e. the court or an enforcement officer. 4. By the provisions of the Constitution, a violation of which is alleged in the constitutional appeal, it has been established that everyone is entitled to the right that an independent and impartial court, established by law, in a fair trial and within a reasonable time, publicly hears and decides his rights and duties, the grounds of the suspicion underlying the charges and institution of the proceedings against him,  Article 32 1 , and that equal protection of rights before courts and other government bodies, bodies entrusted with public powers and autonomous province bodies and local self-governance units, is guaranteed  Article 36 1 . The Law on Enforcement and Security  RS Official Gazette, nos. 31 11, 99 11 and 109 13   CC Decision  regulates  that enforcement of rulings pertaining to family relations and reinstatement of employees to work falls exclusively within the jurisdiction of courts  Article 3 1 ; that, pursuant to Article 29  1 and 2 of this law, an enforcement motion and an enforcement ruling must include the names of the enforcement creditor and enforcement debtor, their addresses, an enforcement document or other authentic document and the unsettled obligation of the enforcement debtor; that in an enforcement motion the enforcement creditor states both the means and objects of enforcement, i.e. the motion must include a claim that the enforcement is to be conducted on the enforcement debtor s entire property, as well as other data necessary for the enforcement procedure; that in commercial matters, when an enforcement debtor is a legal person, an entrepreneur or a natural person who pursues activities for obtainment of profit and has an open account pursuant to payments regulations, it is necessary that the enforcement motion or enforcement ruling, in addition to the obligatory content prescribed under paragraph 1 of this Article, include the following data  personal identification numbers of the parties, i.e. tax payers  identification numbers, or in case of foreign legal persons - corresponding identification numbers, and bank account numbers of the enforcement creditor and debtor in commercial banks with the banks  names; that an enforcement motion based on an authentic document must contain a request that the court obliges the debtor to settle its debt, together with the estimated costs; that, in addition to the enforcement motion, the enforcement creditor is obliged to submit an enforcement document or an authentic document, its original, a certified copy or a transcript, as well as other documents where envisaged by law, and that an enforcement document must include the clause of validity, except where enforcement of non-final decisions is allowed by law; that a foreign authentic document a claim is based on must be submitted in translation to the official language of the court, certified by a court interpreter; that in an enforcement motion it must be indicated whether the enforcement shall be carried out by the court or an enforcement officer and that at least four copies of the enforcement motion shall be submitted  Article 35   1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 ; that an enforcement motion based on an authentic document, submitted for the purpose of settling monetary claims on the ground of provided utility services is submitted to the enforcement officer in whose area the seat of the enforcement creditor is located  Article 252 1 . 5. When considering the constitutional appeal in the light of the alleged violation of the right to a fair trial under Article 32 1 of the Constitution, the Constitutional Court has established that the appellant, as the enforcement creditor, filed through its legal representatives an enforcement motion based on an authentic document in which it was stated that the enforcement debtor did not, even after the payment deadlines had expired, settle its invoice obligations, and proposed that the Belgrade Commercial Court, subsequently to conducted proceedigs and presented evidence, make its ruling and enforce the enforcement motion. With its disputed ruling, the enforcement court rejected as ungrounded the applellant s complaint and upheld the ruling which rejected the appellant s enforcement motion as incomplete, due to the fact that the enforcement debtor did not indicate whether the enforcement was to be conducted by the court or an enforcement officer. Firstly, the Constitutional Court points out that there are two phases to enforcement proceedings, namely  phase one, in which the enforcement motion is decided, and which includes reception of an enforcement motion, assessment of evidence and making the decision, and phase two, in which enforcement is conducted, either by a court   where the court issues an order  a conclusion  to a court enforcement officer to start enforcement and schedules the place, date and time of enforcement, or by an enforcement officer who directly conducts the enforcement. In enforcement proceedings the court acts on the basis of the submitted briefs and other written submissions, holding a hearing only when expedient. By the provision under Article 35 6 of the Law on Enforcement and Security, it is regulated that in an enforcement motion it must be indicated whether the enforcement shall be conducted by the court or an enforcement officer. The enforcement debtor cannot choose the manner of enforcement in the areas where the Law on Enforcement and Security has envisaged exclusive jurisdiction of courts or enforcement officers. Exclusive jurisdiction of courts is enforcement in family relations and reinstitution of employees to work, while exclusive jurisdiction of enforcement officers is enforcement of claims on the ground of provided utility or similar services  telephone bills, electric power, heating, monthly maintanance and parking bills, etc. . Bearing in mind the aforestated and the fact that the enforcement motion of the enforcement creditor, here in the capacity of the appellant, has been filed on the basis of an authentic document, i.e. an invoice for delivered office material, it can be concluded that, in the instant case, the subject matter does not fall under exclusive enforcement jurisdicition of either courts or enforcement officers. The enforcement creditor, i.e. the filer of the enforcement claim, pointed out in the enforcement claim that the enforcement court was to decide the enforcement claim, and subsequently conduct the enforcement, while the enforcement court considered that such specification of the manner of enforcement could not be considered specified as to by whom the enforcement was to be conducted   whether by a court or an enforcement officer. The Constitutional Court here refers to a standpoint in the ECHR case-law, stating that courts are obliged to apply rules of procedure avoiding both exegerated formalism, which could jeopardise the fairness of the proceedings, and exegerrated flexibility, which could render the procedural requirements, envisaged by law, worthless  null, meaninglness   see Eºim v. Turkey, 59601 09 of 17 September 2013 . Dismissing an enforcement motion based on an authentic document for the enforcement of which no exclusive jurisdiction has been envisaged of either courts or enforcement officers, in which it has been indicated that the enforcement court was to rule on the motion, and then enforce the ruling, does not stand for much flexibility. The Constitutional Court has made an assessment, however, that the dismissal of an enforcement motion based on an authentic document, in which, among other things, it has been indicated that the court is to conduct enforcement, as incomplete, with a reasoning that such motion  cannot be considered specific regarding the manner of enforcement in respect of who shall enforce the ruling, a court or enforcement officer , does represent exaggerated formalism of the enforcement court, which as a consequence, has violated the appellants right to a fair trial, protected under Article 32 1 of the Constitution, and more specifically, the right to access to court. Starting from the aforementioned, and in conformity with the provision under Article 89 1 of the Law on the Constitutional Court  RS Official Gazette, nos. 109 07, 99 11 и 18 13   CC Decision , the Constitutional Court has upheld the constitutional appeal, and established that by the disputed ruling of the Belgrade Commercial Court IPV  Iv . 1124 12 of 25 December 2012, the appellant s right to a fair trial, guaranteed under Article 32 1 of the Constitution, has been violated, and has decided as under point 1  of the enactment terms. 6. The Constitutional Court has made an assessment that the detrimental consequences committed in violation of the stated right may be removed solely by the cancellation of the disputed ruling of the Belgrade Commercial Court IPV  Iv. . 1124 12 of 25 December 2012, and by ordering the competent court to re-decide the appellant s complaint, filed against the Belgrade Commercial Court ruling no. Iv. 17138 12 of 26 November 2012, hence pursuant to Article 89 2 of the Law, it has decided as in the point 2  of the enactment terms. 7. In relation to the alleged violation under Article 36 1 of the Constitution, guaranteeing equal protection of rights before courts and other government bodies, bodies entrusted with public powers and autonomous province bodies and local self-governance units, the Constitutional Court points out that from the content of the guaranteed right under Article 36 1 of the Constitution, it follows that withholding equal protection of rights before courts, i.e. other bodies and organisations, the actions and acts of which may be disputed by means of a constitutional appeal, may arise primarily by unequal proceeding in the same factual and legal situations. The appellant, however, has not supported its allegations by adequate evidence, which represents a requirement for establishing a violation of the right to equal protection before courts. Hence, the Constitutional Court has assessed that the constitutional appeal does not contain constitutional and legal reasons in support of the allegation of a violation of the designated right under Article 36 1 of the Constitution. For this reason, and in conformity with Article 36 1 point 7  of the Law on the Constitutional Court, the Constitutional Court has dismissed the constitutional appeal in this part, as the constitutionally established requirements for conducting the proceedings have not been met in this case, and has ruled as in the second part of point 1  of the enactment terms. 8. In addition, the Constitutional Court, pursuant to Article 49 2 of the Law on the Constitutional Court, has decided to publish this decision in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia, in view of its wider relevance for the protection of human rights and civil freedoms, guaranteed by the Constitution. 9. On the basis of the aforestated and the provisions of Article 42b 1, point 1 , Article 45, point 9  and Article 46 point 9  of the Law on the Constitutional Court, as well as Article 89 of the Rules of Procedure of the Constitutional Court   RS Official Gazette, no. 103 13 , the Court has decided as in the enactment terms. THE CHAMBER PRESIDENT Vesna Iliæ Preliæ

that an enforcement motion based on an authentic document, submitted for the purpose of settling monetary claims on the ground of provided utility services is submitted to the enforcement officer in whose area the seat of the enforcement creditor is located  Article 252 1 . 5. When considering the constitutional appeal in the light of the alleged violation of the right to a fair trial under Article 32 1 of the Constitution, the Constitutional Court has established that the appellant, as the enforcement creditor, filed through its legal representatives an enforcement motion based on an authentic document in which it was stated that the enforcement debtor did not, even after the payment deadlines had expired, settle its invoice obligations, and proposed that the Belgrade Commercial Court, subsequently to conducted proceedigs and presented evidence, make its ruling and enforce the enforcement motion. With its disputed ruling, the enforcement court rejected as ungrounded the applellant s complaint and upheld the ruling which rejected the appellant s enforcement motion as incomplete, due to the fact that the enforcement debtor did not indicate whether the enforcement was to be conducted by the court or an enforcement officer. Firstly, the Constitutional Court points out that there are two phases to enforcement proceedings, namely  phase one, in which the enforcement motion is decided, and which includes reception of an enforcement motion, assessment of evidence and making the decision, and phase two, in which enforcement is conducted, either by a court   where the court issues an order  a conclusion  to a court enforcement officer to start enforcement and schedules the place, date and time of enforcement, or by an enforcement officer who directly conducts the enforcement. In enforcement proceedings the court acts on the basis of the submitted briefs and other written submissions, holding a hearing only when expedient. By the provision under Article 35 6 of the Law on Enforcement and Security, it is regulated that in an enforcement motion it must be indicated whether the enforcement shall be conducted by the court or an enforcement officer. The enforcement debtor cannot choose the manner of enforcement in the areas where the Law on Enforcement and Security has envisaged exclusive jurisdiction of courts or enforcement officers. Exclusive jurisdiction of courts is enforcement in family relations and reinstitution of employees to work, while exclusive jurisdiction of enforcement officers is enforcement of claims on the ground of provided utility or similar services  telephone bills, electric power, heating, monthly maintanance and parking bills, etc. . Bearing in mind the aforestated and the fact that the enforcement motion of the enforcement creditor, here in the capacity of the appellant, has been filed on the basis of an authentic document, i.e. an invoice for delivered office material, it can be concluded that, in the instant case, the subject matter does not fall under exclusive enforcement jurisdicition of either courts or enforcement officers. The enforcement creditor, i.e. the filer of the enforcement claim, pointed out in the enforcement claim that the enforcement court was to decide the enforcement claim, and subsequently conduct the enforcement, while the enforcement court considered that such specification of the manner of enforcement could not be considered specified as to by whom the enforcement was to be conducted   whether by a court or an enforcement officer. The Constitutional Court here refers to a standpoint in the ECHR case-law, stating that courts are obliged to apply rules of procedure avoiding both exegerated formalism, which could jeopardise the fairness of the proceedings, and exegerrated flexibility, which could render the procedural requirements, envisaged by law, worthless  null, meaninglness   see Eºim v. Turkey, 59601 09 of 17 September 2013 . Dismissing an enforcement motion based on an authentic document for the enforcement of which no exclusive jurisdiction has been envisaged of either courts or enforcement officers, in which it has been indicated that the enforcement court was to rule on the motion, and then enforce the ruling, does not stand for much flexibility. The Constitutional Court has made an assessment, however, that the dismissal of an enforcement motion based on an authentic document, in which, among other things, it has been indicated that the court is to conduct enforcement, as incomplete, with a reasoning that such motion  cannot be considered specific regarding the manner of enforcement in respect of who shall enforce the ruling, a court or enforcement officer , does represent exaggerated formalism of the enforcement court, which as a consequence, has violated the appellants right to a fair trial, protected under Article 32 1 of the Constitution, and more specifically, the right to access to court. Starting from the aforementioned, and in conformity with the provision under Article 89 1 of the Law on the Constitutional Court  RS Official Gazette, nos. 109 07, 99 11 и 18 13   CC Decision , the Constitutional Court has upheld the constitutional appeal, and established that by the disputed ruling of the Belgrade Commercial Court IPV  Iv . 1124 12 of 25 December 2012, the appellant s right to a fair trial, guaranteed under Article 32 1 of the Constitution, has been violated, and has decided as under point 1  of the enactment terms. 6. The Constitutional Court has made an assessment that the detrimental consequences committed in violation of the stated right may be removed solely by the cancellation of the disputed ruling of the Belgrade Commercial Court IPV  Iv. . 1124 12 of 25 December 2012, and by ordering the competent court to re-decide the appellant s complaint, filed against the Belgrade Commercial Court ruling no. Iv. 17138 12 of 26 November 2012, hence pursuant to Article 89 2 of the Law, it has decided as in the point 2  of the enactment terms. 7. In relation to the alleged violation under Article 36 1 of the Constitution, guaranteeing equal protection of rights before courts and other government bodies, bodies entrusted with public powers and autonomous province bodies and local self-governance units, the Constitutional Court points out that from the content of the guaranteed right under Article 36 1 of the Constitution, it follows that withholding equal protection of rights before courts, i.e. other bodies and organisations, the actions and acts of which may be disputed by means of a constitutional appeal, may arise primarily by unequal proceeding in the same factual and legal situations. The appellant, however, has not supported its allegations by adequate evidence, which represents a requirement for establishing a violation of the right to equal protection before courts. Hence, the Constitutional Court has assessed that the constitutional appeal does not contain constitutional and legal reasons in support of the allegation of a violation of the designated right under Article 36 1 of the Constitution. For this reason, and in conformity with Article 36 1 point 7  of the Law on the Constitutional Court, the Constitutional Court has dismissed the constitutional appeal in this part, as the constitutionally established requirements for conducting the proceedings have not been met in this case, and has ruled as in the second part of point 1  of the enactment terms. 8. In addition, the Constitutional Court, pursuant to Article 49 2 of the Law on the Constitutional Court, has decided to publish this decision in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia, in view of its wider relevance for the protection of human rights and civil freedoms, guaranteed by the Constitution. 9. On the basis of the aforestated and the provisions of Article 42b 1, point 1 , Article 45, point 9  and Article 46 point 9  of the Law on the Constitutional Court, as well as Article 89 of the Rules of Procedure of the Constitutional Court   RS Official Gazette, no. 103 13 , the Court has decided as in the enactment terms. THE CHAMBER PRESIDENT Vesna Iliæ Preliæ

sections.full_text: Identification  SRB-2013-2-004 Už-5284 2011 18.04.2013 THE REPUBLIC OF SERBIA THE CONSTITUTIONAL COURT No  Už- 5284 2011 date  ______ 2013 B e l g r a de The Constitutional court, Grand Chamber consisting of  the President of the Court Dr. Dragisa B.Slijepcevic, in the capacity of the president of the Chamber and the judges Vesna Ilic Prelic, Dr. Marija Draskic, Dr. Agnes Kartag Odri, Dr. Goran Ilic, Sabahudin Tahirovic, Dr. Dragan Stojanoviæ and Milan Markovic LL.M, members of the Chamber, in the proceedings under the constitutional appeal lodged by the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd  from Belgrade and Sonja Gabelic Spicer, Darko Kenig, Goran Miletic, Slobodan Stojanovic, Jovanka Todorovic Savovic and Adam Puskar, all from Belgrade, pursuant to article 167, paragraph 4 in relation to article 170 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, on the sitting held on 18th April 2013 passed the following  D E C I S I O N 1. The constitutional appeal of the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd  is upheld and it is determined that the appellant s right on judicial protection under article 22, par.1 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, the right to legal remedy under article 36, par.2 of the Constitution and freedom of assembly under article 54 of the Constitution are violated by the Decision of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Police Department   Police Department for the city of Belgrade   Police station Savski venac no. 212-613 11 as of 30th September 2011; whereas in the remaining part the constitutional appeal is dismissed as ungrounded. 2. The Court establishes the right of the appellant the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd  on the reimbursement of non-pecuniary damage in the amount of EUR 500 in RSD counter value at middle rate of the National Bank of Serbia on the day of payment. The reimbursement shall be paid from the budgetary resources   section of the Ministry of Justice and Public Administration. 3. The appellant s claim for reimbursement of physical damage is dismissed. 4. The constitutional appeal lodged by Sonja Gabelic Spicer, Darko Kenig, Goran Miletic, Slobodan Stojanovic, Jovanka Todorovic Savovic and Adam Puskar is dismissed. R a t i o n a l e 1. Sonja Gabelic Spicer, Darko Kenig, Goran Miletic, Slobodan Stojanovic, Jovanka Todorovic Savovic and Adam Puskar, all from Belgrade lodged on 31.10.2011, through the attorney of the Belgrade centre for human rights from Belgrade the constitutional appeal to the Constitutional court against the Decision of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Police Department   Police Department for the city of Belgrade   Police station Savski venac no. 212-613 11 as of 30th September 2011, the acts of the state bodies of authority conducted by  default or rather the act of omission of the state bodies of authority, MIA before all, to do everything in their power to prevent violence against participants of Pride parade performed by third parties; i.e. to prevent discrimination against them  as well as on the grounds of  the act of omission of the state bodies of authority to facilitate to them judicial protection and effective legal remedy against the mentioned violation of human rights.  The constitutional appeal is lodged on the grounds of violation of the freedom of assembly guaranteed under article 54 of the Constitution  in relation to the freedom of expression guaranteed under article 46 of the Constitution , violation of the principle of prohibition of discrimination under article 21 of the Constitution as well as the violation of the right on judicial protection under article 22, par.1 of the Constitution and the right to legal remedy guaranteed under provisions of article 36, par.2 of the Constitution. The appellants at the same time invoke the violation of the corresponding provisions of the European convention for protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms which guarantee the mentioned constitutional rights and principles. The appellants  claims that have to be decided upon by the Constitutional court demand from the Court, among other things, to determine the right of the appellants on the reimbursement of the physical damage  for the costs they incurred for the arrangement of the Pride parade  as well as to determine the right on reimbursement of non-pecuniary damage. 2. Pursuant to article 170 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, the constitutional appeal may be lodged against individual legal acts and activities of state bodies of authority or organizations vested with delegated public authorities, whose legal acts or actions either violate or deny human or minority rights and freedoms guaranteed under the Constitution only in case when all other legal remedies have been exhausted or if any other legal remedy has not been envisaged for the protection of the rights of the appellants. In the course of the procedure of providing constitutional judicial protection, with regard to examination of the merits of the constitutional appeal within the limits of the set claim, the Constitutional court determines whether in the procedure of deciding on the appellant s rights and obligations its right or freedom guaranteed under the Constitution was violated   denied or not. From the above it follows that the presumptions for lodging a constitutional legal remedy, among other things, is that a state body of authority decided on a certain right or obligation of the appellant by the disputed legal act or action, since only such legal act of action may be capable to violate any of its guaranteed rights and freedoms as well as that, before addressing the Constitutional court the appellant attempted to protect its rights within the prescribed procedure before the competent authorities. The Constitutional court found that for the purpose of examination of fulfillment of requirements for hearing the lodged constitutional appeal it is necessary to previously determine the state of facts and circumstances of the particular case. 3. The essence of the constitutional appeal yields a conclusion, stated also by the appellants themselves, that the allegations on the violation of the guaranteed rights and freedoms and the principles envisaged by the Constitution are based on the identical statements and arguments which were stated in the constitutional appeal lodged against the individual legal act and activities of the state bodies of authority related to the failure to hold public assembly   Pride parade 2009, whereof the Constitutional court passed the Decision Už-1918 2009 on 22.12.2011. The mentioned Decision of the Constitutional court in the first paragraph of the enacting clause upheld the constitutional appeal of the appellants   natural persons, who were the organizers of the public assembly and determined that the decision of the Police Directorate of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Serbia 03 no.8988 09-20 dated 19.09.2009 violated the appellants  freedom of assembly under article 54, par.1 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia and the right to legal remedy under article 36, par. 2, of the Constitution in relation to article 22, par.1 of the Constitution while in the second paragraph of the enacting clause it is determined that the Decision shall be published in  Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia.  4. In the conducted procedure on the basis of the documentation attached with the constitutional appeal as well as the reply and the documents attached with the reply of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Police Directorate   Police department for the city of Belgrade 03 no. 212-335 12-1 dated 09.03.2012 and no. 212-335 12-1 dated 19.03.2012, the Constitutional court determined the following state of facts and circumstances significant for the hearing of the lodged constitutional appeal. In accordance with the Decision no. BU 12026 2010 as of 31.12.2010 of the Registrar of the Serbian Business Registers Agency in charge of the Register of associations, an entry was made of the registration of the association of citizens under the name of Association  Parada ponosa Beograd , with its registered office in Belgrade and the registered representative of the Association Mr.Slobodan Stojanovic from Belgrade. The Association  Parada ponosa Beograd , through its authorized representative submitted the application on 26.08.2011, to  the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Department of Internal Affairs of Belgrade   Savski venac  for  public manifestation  Belgrade Pride parade 2011  which will consist of public assembly and public assembly in motion . Public assembly and public assembly in motion were registered for 02.10.2011. The disputed Decision of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   the Police Directorate   the Police Department for the city of Belgrade   Police station of Savski venac no. 212-613 11 dated 30.09.2011 prohibited holding of public assembly and public assembly in motion of the organizer   the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd , registered for 02.10.2011 at 11,00 o clock in Belgrade park  Manjez . The second paragraph of the enacting clause of the disputed decision reads that an appeal to the prohibition mentioned in paragraph 1 of the decision does not postpone the enforcement. The decision is passed in relation to the provision of article 11, par.1 of the Law on Public Assembly, and in the reasoning it was outlined that in the procedure conducted under the submitted notification of public assembly it was determined that the reasons under article 11, par.1 of the Law are met; i.e. that the notified public assembly may disrupt public transport, cause threat to public health and morals or endanger the safety of persons and property. The disputed act suggests legal remedy which reads that an appeal may be lodged against the decision within 15 days to the Ministry of Internal Affairs. Beside the disputed decision the competent organizational units of the Ministry of Internal Affairs- the Police Directorate   the Police Department for the city of Belgrade passed on the same day - 30.09.2011 the decisions on prohibiting the holding of all public assemblies and public assemblies in motion registered for 1st and 2nd October 2011. Therefore, the decisions of the competent police stations in the region of the Police Department of the city of Belgrade prohibited public assemblies and public assemblies in motion of the organizer   the Association  Istinoljublje   the Decision of the Police station Stari grad no. 212-963 11 ; the organizer   the Association  Otacastveni pokret Obraz   the Decision of the Police station Vracar no. 01 2. 212-216 ; the organizer  Ekoloski pokret Novog Sada   the Decision of the Police station Stari grad no. 212-1062 11 . On 21.09.2011 also the organizer  Delije Sever  submitted to the Police station Savski venac the registration of public assembly for 01.10.2011 at 20,30 o clock, yet before the passing of the decision on prohibition the organizer notified the competent authority of the cancellation of the registered assembly. The contents of the decision on prohibiting all mentioned public assemblies and the reasons which form the basis of that prohibition are identical to the contents and the reasons of the disputed decision. The passing of all the decisions of prohibiting the public assemblies and the public assemblies in motion registered for 1st and 2nd October 2011 was preceded by security assessment of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Police Directorate   the Police Department of the City of Belgrade classif. no. 216-125 11 dated 28.09.2011 containing in detail all information to which the competent authority has come by way of operation, which are significant for the safety of both the participants of the notified assemblies and citizens that happen to be on the places envisaged for holding such assemblies. The mentioned security assessment that also outlined the fact that on 2nd October 2011 the public order would be violated to a large scale and personal as well as public property injured And the facilities of diplomatic and consular missions of other countries in Belgrade damaged, was construed on the basis of previously gathered specific, explicitly set facts and data. 5. As it was stated in the rationale of the constitutional appeal that one of the appellants is also the association  Parada ponosa Beograd , the legal entity established for the purpose of organization of this manifestation, and the appeal was accompanied with the decision of the Serbian Business Registers Agency on entry of the association  Parada ponosa Beograd  into the Register of associations, wherein the registered representative of the association is Slobodan Stojanovic from Belgrade who is one of the applicants of the constitutional appeal, the Constitutional court required from attorney by its letter of 29.02.2012 to state whether this person lodged the constitutional appeal as an individual on his own behalf or as the registered representative of the Association. The attorney informed the court that Slobodan Stojanovic from Belgrade lodged the constitutional appeal in the capacity of the registered representative of the association  Parada ponosa Beograd  as well as in his own name. In accordance with the above, the Constitutional court determined that, contrary to the state of facts related to the constitutional appeal that the Constitutional court decided upon in the case no. Uz-1918 2009, the organizers of the public assembly and the public assembly in motion  Pride parade 2011  were not natural persons but legal entity   the registered association  Parada ponosa Beograd  from Belgrade. Since the disputed individual legal act   and the acts of omission of the competent bodies of authority related to it  decided on the rights of the organizer of the public assembly, as the holding of the notified assembly is prohibited to the organizer itself, the Constitutional court estimated that in this particular case only the association  Parada ponosa Beograd  has legal capacity to lodge the constitutional appeal and not natural persons designated as the applicants of the constitutional appeal, who on the basis of the submitted and gathered documentation had more or less defined roles and tasks within the very organization of this public assembly. Therefore, the Constitutional court, pursuant to provisions of article 36, par.1, point 7 of the Constitutional Court Act  Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia no.109 07, 99 11 and 18 13   Decision of the Constitutional court , dismissed the constitutional appeal of the appellants Sonja Gabelic Spicer, Darko Kenig, Goran Miletic, Slobodan Stojanovic, Jovanka Todorovic Savovic and Adam Puskar, since the requirements for conducting the proceedings set forth under the Constitution were not fulfilled. 6. The next procedural question that the Constitutional court is obliged to respond to, in relation to the constitutional appeal of the appellant the association  Parada ponosa Beograd , refers to the fulfillment of the requirement set forth under the Constitution; namely whether all legal instruments for protection of the appellant s rights had been previously exhausted. As a matter of fact, and again contrary to the disputed legal act that was the subject of the examination by the Constitutional court in the case no. Uz-1918 2009, the decision that is attacked under this constitutional appeal contains instructions on legal remedy   exercise of the right to appeal. The appellant does not dispute that it did not exhaust the prescribed legal remedy that it has been referred to and states the reasons for not doing so, considering the prescribed legal remedy as ineffective. The court finds that in order to address the previous question it is necessary to consider the contents of the rights and freedoms guaranteed under the constitution whose violation is invoked by the appellant as well as the contents of the corresponding provisions of the Law on Public Assembly which was the basis for passing the disputed legal act. The provision of article 22, par.1 of the Constitution, as one of the principles for exercising all guaranteed rights and freedoms, establishes among other things, the right of every person on judicial protection in cases of violation or denial of any human or minority right guaranteed under the Constitution. Article 36, par. 2 of the Constitution guarantees to every person the right to appeal or to another legal remedy against a decision which decides on their right, obligation or legally based interest. The provisions of article 54 of the Constitution guarantee the freedom of assembly establishing the following  peaceful assembly of citizens is free  paragraph 1 , assembly indoors is not subject to any approval or notification  paragraph 2 , assemblies, demonstrations and other public gatherings outdoors are subject to registration with the state bodies of authority pursuant to the law  paragraph 3  and freedom of assembly may be limited by law only in case it is necessary for the purpose of protection of public health, morals and rights of other people or safety of the Republic of Serbia  paragraph 4 . Provisions of article 11 of the Law on Public Assembly  Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia no.51 92, 53 93, 67 93, 11 99, 33 99 and 48 94, Official Journal of FRY, no.21 01   Decision of the Constitutional court of FRY and Official Gazette of RS no.29 01 and 101 05  which formed the basis for passing the disputed as well as all other decisions prohibiting public assemblies and public assemblies in motion registered for 1st and 2nd October 2011, envisage that a competent authority  the Ministry of Internal Affairs   the organizational unit in the field of public assemblies  may prohibit the holding of a public assembly in order to prevent disruption of public transport, threat to public health and morals or danger the safety of persons and property  paragraph 1 , that the competent authority is obliged to inform the organizer of the prohibition of holding the public assembly at the latest 12 hours before the time the assembly was scheduled  paragraph 2  and also that a prospective appeal to the prohibition under paragraph 1 of this article does not postpone the enforcement of the decision  paragraph 1 . Neither this nor any other provision of the Law prescribes the period for lodging an appeal against the first instance decision on prohibition of public assembly, nor does it regulate the proceedings under the appeal, which means that there should be applied the provisions of the General Administrative Procedure Act, both in terms of lodging the appeal against the decision  within 15 days from the date of serving the first instance legal act  and the periods for passing the decision by the second instance body of authority on the lodged appeal  30, or 60 days . On the basis of these provisions of the law, and bearing in mind the essence of the right to a legal remedy and freedom of assembly guaranteed under the Constitution, the Constitutional court determined that the Law in case of the prohibition of public assembly under Article 11 of the law, formally envisages an appeal as a legal remedy for protection of freedom of assembly of the organizer but the presribed period within which the competent authority is obliged to inform the organizer of the prohibition, then the provision that the appeal does not postpone the prohibition and finally permission to lodge an appeal and hearing the appeal in accordance with the rules of the general administrative procedure in essence does not provide effective protection of this freedom. Considering that it is undisputed that in this particular case the decision on the appeal lodged against the decision passed on Friday 30.09.2011, in relation to the prohibition of public assembly registered for Sunday, 02.10.2011 at 11,00 o clock, would have a post-hoc protective effect, the Constitutional court took the stand that such protection objectively could not be timely provided and thus could not be effective. Therefore, the court found that in this particular case, the constitutional appeal of the appellant - the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd  is allowed, although the appellant did not exhaust all other legal remedies for protection of their rights before addressing the Constitutional court. The Constitutional court took the same stand in the mentioned Decision no. Uz-1918 2009 dated 22.12.2011. The merits of such assessment of the Constitutional court are further confirmed also by the attitude of the European Court of Human Rights expressed in the decision Baczkowski and others v. Poland in accordance with which in cases which refer to freedom of assembly, in order to consider a legal remedy effective it has to oblige the competent body of authority to pass a decision in the manner that the final decision is passed before the date for which the particular assembly had been schedulled  judgement as of 03.05.2007, paragraph 83 , to which the applicant itself referred to in its constitutional appeal. 7. When assessing the merits of the constitutional appeal in relation to the stated cases of violation of the rights and freedoms guaranteed under the Constitution, and based on the previously determined facts and circumstances of the particular case, the Constitutional court took into account the following  Firstly, freedom of assembly under article 54 of the Constitution is not absolute but its exercise is subject to limitations envisaged by the Constitution. On one hand, citizens are only guaranteed freedom of peaceful assembly, which means that the constitutional guarantees of this freedom do not refer to assembly which is not peaceful. On the other hand, the framers of the Constitution allowed the possibility of limiting the guaranteed freedom of assembly on the account of the reasons explicitely defined by the Constitution  1  protection of public health, 2  protection of morals, 3  protection of other persons  rights or 4  protection of security of the Republic of Serbia. Moreover, there is the obligation defined under the Constitution to notify the competent body of authority of the outdoor public assembly in accordance with the law. Secondly, the provisions of article 54 of the Constitution indicatate that the freedom of assembly represents one of the freedoms guaranteed under the Constitution for which in accordance with article 18, paragraph 2 of the Constitution the manner of its exercise is prescribed by law. Thirdly, in the legal system of the Republic of Serbia the manner of exercise of freedom of assembly guaranteed under the Constitution of 2006, regulated by the Law on Public Assembly passed in 1992 which was amended and modified several times during its validity, the latest amendment being in 2005. Based on the analysis of the provisions of the mentioned law it may be concluded that it actually contains two regimes of limiting the freedom of public assembly. Provisions of articles 9 and 10 of the law regulate only the case when the competent authority, i.e. the Ministry of Internal Affairs, only temporarily prohibits holding of public assembly  outdoor public assembly , informs within 12 hours the organizer about the prohibition and within the same period refers to the competent court with the reasoned request for deciding upon the prohibition of that assembly  final decision . In this case, the legislator completely regulated the procedure of the court s decision-making on the prohibition of holding public assembly, that is the procedure which, setting forth the periods for taking particular actions, provides urgency in decision-making, respect of the principle of equalty in the manner that it conducts a hearing inviting both the applicant of the request for prohibition and the organizer, provides two levels of decision-making, in which case the highest court in the Republic decides on the appeal. However, such regulated procedure of limiting the freedom of assembly refers to prohibition of public assembly  which is aimed at violent overthrow of the constitutional order, violation of territorial integrity and independence of the Republic of Serbia, violation of freedoms and rights of individuals and citizens guaranteed by the Constitution, inciting national, racial and religious intollerance and hatred   article 9, paragraph 1 of the Law . Contrary to the above, under provisions of article 11, the same law envisages the prohibition of holding public assembly for the purpose of  prevention of disruption of public transport, causing threat to human health, morals or safety of people or property   article 11, paragraph 1 of the Law  in which case there is no temporary prohibition, nor is there envisaged the court s jurisdiction to decide on the prohibition, but holding of public assembly is prohibited by the competent body of authority  the Ministry  which informs the organizer on the prohibition  at the latest 12 hours before the time the assembly had been scheduled . In this case the Law contains only the provision  paragraph 3 of article 11  that the appeal against the prohibition in paragraph 1 of this article does not postpone the execution of the decision. Fourthly, in this particular case the disputed decision on the prohibition of the notified public assembly and the public assembly in motion has been passed on the basis of article 11 of the Law on Public Assembly. Fifthly, the public assembly was registered for Sunday, 2nd October 2011 at 11 o clock, and the disputed decision was served upon the applicant of the constitutional appeal, in the capacity of the organizer on Sunday, 30th September 2011 during the afternoon. Sixthly, the passing of the disputed legal act was preceded by an extensive and detailed safety assessment of the competent Ministry of internal affairs. Seventhly, on the basis of such safety assessment on the same day i.e. 30th September 2011, the Ministry passed the decisions on prohibition of all public assemblies and public assemblies in motion registered in Belgrade for 1st and 2nd October 2011 Bearing in mind the above, the Constitutional court estimated that regardless of the fact that in this particular case the collected data do not facilitate a reliable basis for the conslusion that the competent body of authority passed the disputed decision on the account of arbitrary assessment of relevant circumstances significant for the protection of the guaranteed rights on phyisical integrity, freedom of movement and property of the citizens that would happen to find themselves in the place envisaged for the public assembly and the public assembly in motion at the time of the assembly as well as for protection of the right on physical and mental integrity of the participants of the registered assembly, and also regardless of the fact that the competent body of authority was obliged by the provisions of the effective law, so that pursuant to the law the competent body passed the disputed decision and served it upon the organizer, the very impossiblity of the applicant to use an effective legal remedy in the procedure where they would be given judicial protection, to require the review of the decision limiting one of the freedoms guaranteed under the Constitution, represents violation of the right to judicial protection under article 22, paragraph 1 of the Constitution and the right to legal remedy under article 36, paragraph 2 of the Constitution, and consequently the violation of freedom of asssembly under article 54 of the Constitution. Therefore, pursuant to provisions of article 89, paragraph 1 of the Constitutional court Act, the Constitutional court upheld the constitutional appeal in this part. The Constitutional court establishes that the disputed action  the act of omission of the state bodies of authority to provide judicial protection and effective legal remedy against the mentioned violation of human rights  was consumed by determination of violations in relation to the disputed decision of the Ministry of internal affairs   Police Directorate   Police Department of the city of Belgrade   Police station of Savski venac no. 212-613 11 dated 30th September 2011. 8. On the basis of the provision of article 89 paragraph 2 of the Constitutional Court Act, the Constitutional court decided that the just satisfaction of the appellant   the association  Parada ponosa Beograd  due to the established violations of the rights shall be exercised through establishment of the right on reimbursement of non-pecuniary damage in the amount of EUR 500 in dinar counter value. In accordance with the estimate of the Constitutional court, the violations of the rights are a consequence of the manner in which the exercise of the freedom of assembly is regulated by the effective law, to which the Constitutional court already drew the attention of the legislator, pointing out the need to harmonize the Law on Public Assembly with the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia of 2006 in order to eliminate the problems in achieving the constitutionality of this area. Bearing in mind the above, and also the fact that the Constitutional court on its session held on 22.12.2011 passed the Decision no. Uz-1918 2009, whereby it established the violation of freedom of assembly under article 54, paragraph 1 of the Constitution and the right on legal instrument under article 36, paragraph 2 of the Constitution, in relation to article 22, paragraph 1 of the Constitution of the appellants   natural persons who were some of the organizers of public assembly  Pride parade 2009 , determining at that time the publishing of the Decision in  Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia  as a form of just satisfaction of the appellants, and also that now the organizer of the prohibited public assembly is the particular legal entity, the Constitutional Court finds that there is the reasonable basis to determine the reimbursement of non-pecuniary damage to the appellant, in the amount which is adequate for the purpose of this reimbursement, in this case as a specific form of warning due to the recurrent violation of the right. The Constitutional court dismissed the claim of this appellant for the reimbursement of material damage since were are no presumptions for decision-making defined by article 85, par.1 and 2 of the Constitutional court Act. 9. In relation to the disputed actions of the state bodies of authority performed by  the act of omission, or rather failure of the state bodies of authority, MIA before all, to do everything in their power to prevent violence against the participants of the Pride parade by third parties, or rather to prevent discrimination against them,  the Constitutional court reiterates on this occasion that in cases where a public assembly was not held and when holding of all other public assemblies registered for the same or about the same time as the time of the public assembly of the appellant are prohibited, there is no reasonable basis for the allegations of a violation of the rights.
