With referrence to the stated violation of the principle of prohibition of discrimination under article 21 of the Constitution, the Constitutional court estimated that the fact that the competent authority prohibited all public assemblies and public assemblies in motion registered for the same or previous day in relation to the public assembly of the appellant, and whose organizers were persons and organizations which represent the opposed attitudes and ideas, makes constitutionally and legally ungrounded the allegation of the appellant that the prohibition of the public assembly registered by them is a consequence of discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. Therefore the Constitutional court dismissed the constitutional appeal in this part as ungounded, pursuant to article 89, paragraph 1 of the Constitutional Court Act. 10. On the basis of all the above stated and pursuant to provisions of article 426, paragraph 1, point 2 , article 45 point 9, article 46, point 9 and article 47, paragraph 2 of the Constitutional Court Act and article 84 of the Rules of procedure of the Constitutional court   Official Gazette of RS  no.24 08, 27 08 and 76 11  the Constitutional court passed the Decision as in the enacting clause. THE PRESIDENT OF THE CHAMBER Dr. Dragisa B. Slijepcevic см

text: Identification  SRB-2013-2-004 Už-5284 2011 18.04.2013 THE REPUBLIC OF SERBIA THE CONSTITUTIONAL COURT No  Už- 5284 2011 date  ______ 2013 B e l g r a de The Constitutional court, Grand Chamber consisting of  the President of the Court Dr. Dragisa B.Slijepcevic, in the capacity of the president of the Chamber and the judges Vesna Ilic Prelic, Dr. Marija Draskic, Dr. Agnes Kartag Odri, Dr. Goran Ilic, Sabahudin Tahirovic, Dr. Dragan Stojanoviæ and Milan Markovic LL.M, members of the Chamber, in the proceedings under the constitutional appeal lodged by the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd  from Belgrade and Sonja Gabelic Spicer, Darko Kenig, Goran Miletic, Slobodan Stojanovic, Jovanka Todorovic Savovic and Adam Puskar, all from Belgrade, pursuant to article 167, paragraph 4 in relation to article 170 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, on the sitting held on 18th April 2013 passed the following  D E C I S I O N 1. The constitutional appeal of the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd  is upheld and it is determined that the appellant s right on judicial protection under article 22, par.1 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, the right to legal remedy under article 36, par.2 of the Constitution and freedom of assembly under article 54 of the Constitution are violated by the Decision of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Police Department   Police Department for the city of Belgrade   Police station Savski venac no. 212-613 11 as of 30th September 2011; whereas in the remaining part the constitutional appeal is dismissed as ungrounded. 2. The Court establishes the right of the appellant the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd  on the reimbursement of non-pecuniary damage in the amount of EUR 500 in RSD counter value at middle rate of the National Bank of Serbia on the day of payment. The reimbursement shall be paid from the budgetary resources   section of the Ministry of Justice and Public Administration. 3. The appellant s claim for reimbursement of physical damage is dismissed. 4. The constitutional appeal lodged by Sonja Gabelic Spicer, Darko Kenig, Goran Miletic, Slobodan Stojanovic, Jovanka Todorovic Savovic and Adam Puskar is dismissed. R a t i o n a l e 1. Sonja Gabelic Spicer, Darko Kenig, Goran Miletic, Slobodan Stojanovic, Jovanka Todorovic Savovic and Adam Puskar, all from Belgrade lodged on 31.10.2011, through the attorney of the Belgrade centre for human rights from Belgrade the constitutional appeal to the Constitutional court against the Decision of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Police Department   Police Department for the city of Belgrade   Police station Savski venac no. 212-613 11 as of 30th September 2011, the acts of the state bodies of authority conducted by  default or rather the act of omission of the state bodies of authority, MIA before all, to do everything in their power to prevent violence against participants of Pride parade performed by third parties; i.e. to prevent discrimination against them  as well as on the grounds of  the act of omission of the state bodies of authority to facilitate to them judicial protection and effective legal remedy against the mentioned violation of human rights.  The constitutional appeal is lodged on the grounds of violation of the freedom of assembly guaranteed under article 54 of the Constitution  in relation to the freedom of expression guaranteed under article 46 of the Constitution , violation of the principle of prohibition of discrimination under article 21 of the Constitution as well as the violation of the right on judicial protection under article 22, par.1 of the Constitution and the right to legal remedy guaranteed under provisions of article 36, par.2 of the Constitution. The appellants at the same time invoke the violation of the corresponding provisions of the European convention for protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms which guarantee the mentioned constitutional rights and principles. The appellants  claims that have to be decided upon by the Constitutional court demand from the Court, among other things, to determine the right of the appellants on the reimbursement of the physical damage  for the costs they incurred for the arrangement of the Pride parade  as well as to determine the right on reimbursement of non-pecuniary damage. 2. Pursuant to article 170 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia, the constitutional appeal may be lodged against individual legal acts and activities of state bodies of authority or organizations vested with delegated public authorities, whose legal acts or actions either violate or deny human or minority rights and freedoms guaranteed under the Constitution only in case when all other legal remedies have been exhausted or if any other legal remedy has not been envisaged for the protection of the rights of the appellants. In the course of the procedure of providing constitutional judicial protection, with regard to examination of the merits of the constitutional appeal within the limits of the set claim, the Constitutional court determines whether in the procedure of deciding on the appellant s rights and obligations its right or freedom guaranteed under the Constitution was violated   denied or not. From the above it follows that the presumptions for lodging a constitutional legal remedy, among other things, is that a state body of authority decided on a certain right or obligation of the appellant by the disputed legal act or action, since only such legal act of action may be capable to violate any of its guaranteed rights and freedoms as well as that, before addressing the Constitutional court the appellant attempted to protect its rights within the prescribed procedure before the competent authorities. The Constitutional court found that for the purpose of examination of fulfillment of requirements for hearing the lodged constitutional appeal it is necessary to previously determine the state of facts and circumstances of the particular case. 3. The essence of the constitutional appeal yields a conclusion, stated also by the appellants themselves, that the allegations on the violation of the guaranteed rights and freedoms and the principles envisaged by the Constitution are based on the identical statements and arguments which were stated in the constitutional appeal lodged against the individual legal act and activities of the state bodies of authority related to the failure to hold public assembly   Pride parade 2009, whereof the Constitutional court passed the Decision Už-1918 2009 on 22.12.2011. The mentioned Decision of the Constitutional court in the first paragraph of the enacting clause upheld the constitutional appeal of the appellants   natural persons, who were the organizers of the public assembly and determined that the decision of the Police Directorate of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Serbia 03 no.8988 09-20 dated 19.09.2009 violated the appellants  freedom of assembly under article 54, par.1 of the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia and the right to legal remedy under article 36, par. 2, of the Constitution in relation to article 22, par.1 of the Constitution while in the second paragraph of the enacting clause it is determined that the Decision shall be published in  Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia.  4. In the conducted procedure on the basis of the documentation attached with the constitutional appeal as well as the reply and the documents attached with the reply of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Police Directorate   Police department for the city of Belgrade 03 no. 212-335 12-1 dated 09.03.2012 and no. 212-335 12-1 dated 19.03.2012, the Constitutional court determined the following state of facts and circumstances significant for the hearing of the lodged constitutional appeal. In accordance with the Decision no. BU 12026 2010 as of 31.12.2010 of the Registrar of the Serbian Business Registers Agency in charge of the Register of associations, an entry was made of the registration of the association of citizens under the name of Association  Parada ponosa Beograd , with its registered office in Belgrade and the registered representative of the Association Mr.Slobodan Stojanovic from Belgrade. The Association  Parada ponosa Beograd , through its authorized representative submitted the application on 26.08.2011, to  the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Department of Internal Affairs of Belgrade   Savski venac  for  public manifestation  Belgrade Pride parade 2011  which will consist of public assembly and public assembly in motion . Public assembly and public assembly in motion were registered for 02.10.2011. The disputed Decision of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   the Police Directorate   the Police Department for the city of Belgrade   Police station of Savski venac no. 212-613 11 dated 30.09.2011 prohibited holding of public assembly and public assembly in motion of the organizer   the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd , registered for 02.10.2011 at 11,00 o clock in Belgrade park  Manjez . The second paragraph of the enacting clause of the disputed decision reads that an appeal to the prohibition mentioned in paragraph 1 of the decision does not postpone the enforcement. The decision is passed in relation to the provision of article 11, par.1 of the Law on Public Assembly, and in the reasoning it was outlined that in the procedure conducted under the submitted notification of public assembly it was determined that the reasons under article 11, par.1 of the Law are met; i.e. that the notified public assembly may disrupt public transport, cause threat to public health and morals or endanger the safety of persons and property. The disputed act suggests legal remedy which reads that an appeal may be lodged against the decision within 15 days to the Ministry of Internal Affairs. Beside the disputed decision the competent organizational units of the Ministry of Internal Affairs- the Police Directorate   the Police Department for the city of Belgrade passed on the same day - 30.09.2011 the decisions on prohibiting the holding of all public assemblies and public assemblies in motion registered for 1st and 2nd October 2011. Therefore, the decisions of the competent police stations in the region of the Police Department of the city of Belgrade prohibited public assemblies and public assemblies in motion of the organizer   the Association  Istinoljublje   the Decision of the Police station Stari grad no. 212-963 11 ; the organizer   the Association  Otacastveni pokret Obraz   the Decision of the Police station Vracar no. 01 2. 212-216 ; the organizer  Ekoloski pokret Novog Sada   the Decision of the Police station Stari grad no. 212-1062 11 . On 21.09.2011 also the organizer  Delije Sever  submitted to the Police station Savski venac the registration of public assembly for 01.10.2011 at 20,30 o clock, yet before the passing of the decision on prohibition the organizer notified the competent authority of the cancellation of the registered assembly. The contents of the decision on prohibiting all mentioned public assemblies and the reasons which form the basis of that prohibition are identical to the contents and the reasons of the disputed decision. The passing of all the decisions of prohibiting the public assemblies and the public assemblies in motion registered for 1st and 2nd October 2011 was preceded by security assessment of the Ministry of Internal Affairs   Police Directorate   the Police Department of the City of Belgrade classif. no. 216-125 11 dated 28.09.2011 containing in detail all information to which the competent authority has come by way of operation, which are significant for the safety of both the participants of the notified assemblies and citizens that happen to be on the places envisaged for holding such assemblies. The mentioned security assessment that also outlined the fact that on 2nd October 2011 the public order would be violated to a large scale and personal as well as public property injured And the facilities of diplomatic and consular missions of other countries in Belgrade damaged, was construed on the basis of previously gathered specific, explicitly set facts and data. 5. As it was stated in the rationale of the constitutional appeal that one of the appellants is also the association  Parada ponosa Beograd , the legal entity established for the purpose of organization of this manifestation, and the appeal was accompanied with the decision of the Serbian Business Registers Agency on entry of the association  Parada ponosa Beograd  into the Register of associations, wherein the registered representative of the association is Slobodan Stojanovic from Belgrade who is one of the applicants of the constitutional appeal, the Constitutional court required from attorney by its letter of 29.02.2012 to state whether this person lodged the constitutional appeal as an individual on his own behalf or as the registered representative of the Association. The attorney informed the court that Slobodan Stojanovic from Belgrade lodged the constitutional appeal in the capacity of the registered representative of the association  Parada ponosa Beograd  as well as in his own name. In accordance with the above, the Constitutional court determined that, contrary to the state of facts related to the constitutional appeal that the Constitutional court decided upon in the case no. Uz-1918 2009, the organizers of the public assembly and the public assembly in motion  Pride parade 2011  were not natural persons but legal entity   the registered association  Parada ponosa Beograd  from Belgrade. Since the disputed individual legal act   and the acts of omission of the competent bodies of authority related to it  decided on the rights of the organizer of the public assembly, as the holding of the notified assembly is prohibited to the organizer itself, the Constitutional court estimated that in this particular case only the association  Parada ponosa Beograd  has legal capacity to lodge the constitutional appeal and not natural persons designated as the applicants of the constitutional appeal, who on the basis of the submitted and gathered documentation had more or less defined roles and tasks within the very organization of this public assembly. Therefore, the Constitutional court, pursuant to provisions of article 36, par.1, point 7 of the Constitutional Court Act  Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia no.109 07, 99 11 and 18 13   Decision of the Constitutional court , dismissed the constitutional appeal of the appellants Sonja Gabelic Spicer, Darko Kenig, Goran Miletic, Slobodan Stojanovic, Jovanka Todorovic Savovic and Adam Puskar, since the requirements for conducting the proceedings set forth under the Constitution were not fulfilled. 6. The next procedural question that the Constitutional court is obliged to respond to, in relation to the constitutional appeal of the appellant the association  Parada ponosa Beograd , refers to the fulfillment of the requirement set forth under the Constitution; namely whether all legal instruments for protection of the appellant s rights had been previously exhausted. As a matter of fact, and again contrary to the disputed legal act that was the subject of the examination by the Constitutional court in the case no. Uz-1918 2009, the decision that is attacked under this constitutional appeal contains instructions on legal remedy   exercise of the right to appeal. The appellant does not dispute that it did not exhaust the prescribed legal remedy that it has been referred to and states the reasons for not doing so, considering the prescribed legal remedy as ineffective. The court finds that in order to address the previous question it is necessary to consider the contents of the rights and freedoms guaranteed under the constitution whose violation is invoked by the appellant as well as the contents of the corresponding provisions of the Law on Public Assembly which was the basis for passing the disputed legal act. The provision of article 22, par.1 of the Constitution, as one of the principles for exercising all guaranteed rights and freedoms, establishes among other things, the right of every person on judicial protection in cases of violation or denial of any human or minority right guaranteed under the Constitution. Article 36, par. 2 of the Constitution guarantees to every person the right to appeal or to another legal remedy against a decision which decides on their right, obligation or legally based interest. The provisions of article 54 of the Constitution guarantee the freedom of assembly establishing the following  peaceful assembly of citizens is free  paragraph 1 , assembly indoors is not subject to any approval or notification  paragraph 2 , assemblies, demonstrations and other public gatherings outdoors are subject to registration with the state bodies of authority pursuant to the law  paragraph 3  and freedom of assembly may be limited by law only in case it is necessary for the purpose of protection of public health, morals and rights of other people or safety of the Republic of Serbia  paragraph 4 . Provisions of article 11 of the Law on Public Assembly  Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia no.51 92, 53 93, 67 93, 11 99, 33 99 and 48 94, Official Journal of FRY, no.21 01   Decision of the Constitutional court of FRY and Official Gazette of RS no.29 01 and 101 05  which formed the basis for passing the disputed as well as all other decisions prohibiting public assemblies and public assemblies in motion registered for 1st and 2nd October 2011, envisage that a competent authority  the Ministry of Internal Affairs   the organizational unit in the field of public assemblies  may prohibit the holding of a public assembly in order to prevent disruption of public transport, threat to public health and morals or danger the safety of persons and property  paragraph 1 , that the competent authority is obliged to inform the organizer of the prohibition of holding the public assembly at the latest 12 hours before the time the assembly was scheduled  paragraph 2  and also that a prospective appeal to the prohibition under paragraph 1 of this article does not postpone the enforcement of the decision  paragraph 1 . Neither this nor any other provision of the Law prescribes the period for lodging an appeal against the first instance decision on prohibition of public assembly, nor does it regulate the proceedings under the appeal, which means that there should be applied the provisions of the General Administrative Procedure Act, both in terms of lodging the appeal against the decision  within 15 days from the date of serving the first instance legal act  and the periods for passing the decision by the second instance body of authority on the lodged appeal  30, or 60 days . On the basis of these provisions of the law, and bearing in mind the essence of the right to a legal remedy and freedom of assembly guaranteed under the Constitution, the Constitutional court determined that the Law in case of the prohibition of public assembly under Article 11 of the law, formally envisages an appeal as a legal remedy for protection of freedom of assembly of the organizer but the presribed period within which the competent authority is obliged to inform the organizer of the prohibition, then the provision that the appeal does not postpone the prohibition and finally permission to lodge an appeal and hearing the appeal in accordance with the rules of the general administrative procedure in essence does not provide effective protection of this freedom. Considering that it is undisputed that in this particular case the decision on the appeal lodged against the decision passed on Friday 30.09.2011, in relation to the prohibition of public assembly registered for Sunday, 02.10.2011 at 11,00 o clock, would have a post-hoc protective effect, the Constitutional court took the stand that such protection objectively could not be timely provided and thus could not be effective. Therefore, the court found that in this particular case, the constitutional appeal of the appellant - the Association  Parada ponosa Beograd  is allowed, although the appellant did not exhaust all other legal remedies for protection of their rights before addressing the Constitutional court. The Constitutional court took the same stand in the mentioned Decision no. Uz-1918 2009 dated 22.12.2011. The merits of such assessment of the Constitutional court are further confirmed also by the attitude of the European Court of Human Rights expressed in the decision Baczkowski and others v. Poland in accordance with which in cases which refer to freedom of assembly, in order to consider a legal remedy effective it has to oblige the competent body of authority to pass a decision in the manner that the final decision is passed before the date for which the particular assembly had been schedulled  judgement as of 03.05.2007, paragraph 83 , to which the applicant itself referred to in its constitutional appeal. 7. When assessing the merits of the constitutional appeal in relation to the stated cases of violation of the rights and freedoms guaranteed under the Constitution, and based on the previously determined facts and circumstances of the particular case, the Constitutional court took into account the following  Firstly, freedom of assembly under article 54 of the Constitution is not absolute but its exercise is subject to limitations envisaged by the Constitution. On one hand, citizens are only guaranteed freedom of peaceful assembly, which means that the constitutional guarantees of this freedom do not refer to assembly which is not peaceful. On the other hand, the framers of the Constitution allowed the possibility of limiting the guaranteed freedom of assembly on the account of the reasons explicitely defined by the Constitution  1  protection of public health, 2  protection of morals, 3  protection of other persons  rights or 4  protection of security of the Republic of Serbia. Moreover, there is the obligation defined under the Constitution to notify the competent body of authority of the outdoor public assembly in accordance with the law. Secondly, the provisions of article 54 of the Constitution indicatate that the freedom of assembly represents one of the freedoms guaranteed under the Constitution for which in accordance with article 18, paragraph 2 of the Constitution the manner of its exercise is prescribed by law. Thirdly, in the legal system of the Republic of Serbia the manner of exercise of freedom of assembly guaranteed under the Constitution of 2006, regulated by the Law on Public Assembly passed in 1992 which was amended and modified several times during its validity, the latest amendment being in 2005. Based on the analysis of the provisions of the mentioned law it may be concluded that it actually contains two regimes of limiting the freedom of public assembly. Provisions of articles 9 and 10 of the law regulate only the case when the competent authority, i.e. the Ministry of Internal Affairs, only temporarily prohibits holding of public assembly  outdoor public assembly , informs within 12 hours the organizer about the prohibition and within the same period refers to the competent court with the reasoned request for deciding upon the prohibition of that assembly  final decision . In this case, the legislator completely regulated the procedure of the court s decision-making on the prohibition of holding public assembly, that is the procedure which, setting forth the periods for taking particular actions, provides urgency in decision-making, respect of the principle of equalty in the manner that it conducts a hearing inviting both the applicant of the request for prohibition and the organizer, provides two levels of decision-making, in which case the highest court in the Republic decides on the appeal. However, such regulated procedure of limiting the freedom of assembly refers to prohibition of public assembly  which is aimed at violent overthrow of the constitutional order, violation of territorial integrity and independence of the Republic of Serbia, violation of freedoms and rights of individuals and citizens guaranteed by the Constitution, inciting national, racial and religious intollerance and hatred   article 9, paragraph 1 of the Law . Contrary to the above, under provisions of article 11, the same law envisages the prohibition of holding public assembly for the purpose of  prevention of disruption of public transport, causing threat to human health, morals or safety of people or property   article 11, paragraph 1 of the Law  in which case there is no temporary prohibition, nor is there envisaged the court s jurisdiction to decide on the prohibition, but holding of public assembly is prohibited by the competent body of authority  the Ministry  which informs the organizer on the prohibition  at the latest 12 hours before the time the assembly had been scheduled . In this case the Law contains only the provision  paragraph 3 of article 11  that the appeal against the prohibition in paragraph 1 of this article does not postpone the execution of the decision. Fourthly, in this particular case the disputed decision on the prohibition of the notified public assembly and the public assembly in motion has been passed on the basis of article 11 of the Law on Public Assembly. Fifthly, the public assembly was registered for Sunday, 2nd October 2011 at 11 o clock, and the disputed decision was served upon the applicant of the constitutional appeal, in the capacity of the organizer on Sunday, 30th September 2011 during the afternoon. Sixthly, the passing of the disputed legal act was preceded by an extensive and detailed safety assessment of the competent Ministry of internal affairs. Seventhly, on the basis of such safety assessment on the same day i.e. 30th September 2011, the Ministry passed the decisions on prohibition of all public assemblies and public assemblies in motion registered in Belgrade for 1st and 2nd October 2011 Bearing in mind the above, the Constitutional court estimated that regardless of the fact that in this particular case the collected data do not facilitate a reliable basis for the conslusion that the competent body of authority passed the disputed decision on the account of arbitrary assessment of relevant circumstances significant for the protection of the guaranteed rights on phyisical integrity, freedom of movement and property of the citizens that would happen to find themselves in the place envisaged for the public assembly and the public assembly in motion at the time of the assembly as well as for protection of the right on physical and mental integrity of the participants of the registered assembly, and also regardless of the fact that the competent body of authority was obliged by the provisions of the effective law, so that pursuant to the law the competent body passed the disputed decision and served it upon the organizer, the very impossiblity of the applicant to use an effective legal remedy in the procedure where they would be given judicial protection, to require the review of the decision limiting one of the freedoms guaranteed under the Constitution, represents violation of the right to judicial protection under article 22, paragraph 1 of the Constitution and the right to legal remedy under article 36, paragraph 2 of the Constitution, and consequently the violation of freedom of asssembly under article 54 of the Constitution. Therefore, pursuant to provisions of article 89, paragraph 1 of the Constitutional court Act, the Constitutional court upheld the constitutional appeal in this part. The Constitutional court establishes that the disputed action  the act of omission of the state bodies of authority to provide judicial protection and effective legal remedy against the mentioned violation of human rights  was consumed by determination of violations in relation to the disputed decision of the Ministry of internal affairs   Police Directorate   Police Department of the city of Belgrade   Police station of Savski venac no. 212-613 11 dated 30th September 2011. 8. On the basis of the provision of article 89 paragraph 2 of the Constitutional Court Act, the Constitutional court decided that the just satisfaction of the appellant   the association  Parada ponosa Beograd  due to the established violations of the rights shall be exercised through establishment of the right on reimbursement of non-pecuniary damage in the amount of EUR 500 in dinar counter value. In accordance with the estimate of the Constitutional court, the violations of the rights are a consequence of the manner in which the exercise of the freedom of assembly is regulated by the effective law, to which the Constitutional court already drew the attention of the legislator, pointing out the need to harmonize the Law on Public Assembly with the Constitution of the Republic of Serbia of 2006 in order to eliminate the problems in achieving the constitutionality of this area. Bearing in mind the above, and also the fact that the Constitutional court on its session held on 22.12.2011 passed the Decision no. Uz-1918 2009, whereby it established the violation of freedom of assembly under article 54, paragraph 1 of the Constitution and the right on legal instrument under article 36, paragraph 2 of the Constitution, in relation to article 22, paragraph 1 of the Constitution of the appellants   natural persons who were some of the organizers of public assembly  Pride parade 2009 , determining at that time the publishing of the Decision in  Official Gazette of the Republic of Serbia  as a form of just satisfaction of the appellants, and also that now the organizer of the prohibited public assembly is the particular legal entity, the Constitutional Court finds that there is the reasonable basis to determine the reimbursement of non-pecuniary damage to the appellant, in the amount which is adequate for the purpose of this reimbursement, in this case as a specific form of warning due to the recurrent violation of the right. The Constitutional court dismissed the claim of this appellant for the reimbursement of material damage since were are no presumptions for decision-making defined by article 85, par.1 and 2 of the Constitutional court Act. 9. In relation to the disputed actions of the state bodies of authority performed by  the act of omission, or rather failure of the state bodies of authority, MIA before all, to do everything in their power to prevent violence against the participants of the Pride parade by third parties, or rather to prevent discrimination against them,  the Constitutional court reiterates on this occasion that in cases where a public assembly was not held and when holding of all other public assemblies registered for the same or about the same time as the time of the public assembly of the appellant are prohibited, there is no reasonable basis for the allegations of a violation of the rights. With referrence to the stated violation of the principle of prohibition of discrimination under article 21 of the Constitution, the Constitutional court estimated that the fact that the competent authority prohibited all public assemblies and public assemblies in motion registered for the same or previous day in relation to the public assembly of the appellant, and whose organizers were persons and organizations which represent the opposed attitudes and ideas, makes constitutionally and legally ungrounded the allegation of the appellant that the prohibition of the public assembly registered by them is a consequence of discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. Therefore the Constitutional court dismissed the constitutional appeal in this part as ungounded, pursuant to article 89, paragraph 1 of the Constitutional Court Act. 10. On the basis of all the above stated and pursuant to provisions of article 426, paragraph 1, point 2 , article 45 point 9, article 46, point 9 and article 47, paragraph 2 of the Constitutional Court Act and article 84 of the Rules of procedure of the Constitutional court   Official Gazette of RS  no.24 08, 27 08 and 76 11  the Constitutional court passed the Decision as in the enacting clause. THE PRESIDENT OF THE CHAMBER Dr. Dragisa B. Slijepcevic см

sections.full_text: Identification  GEO-2002-1-001 Identification  GEO-2002-1-002 8 177 2 21.05.2002 J U D G E M E N T OF THE PLENUM OF THE CONSTITUTIONAL COURT OF GEORGIA   8 177 2 Tbilisi, May 21, 2002 The Plenum of the Constitutional Court of Georgia with the following composition  John Khetsuriani  chairman of the sitting , Nikoloz Shashkin, Avtandil Abashidze, Otar Benidze, Besarion Zoidze, Jacob Putkaradze, Nikoloz Cherkezishvili, Lamara Chorgolashvili, Zaur Jinjolava  reporting judge , secretary of the sitting - Lili Melashvili, with participation of  invited experts  the chief consultant of the President of Georgia in the field of the International Law, Member of the Academy of Sciences of Georgia, Doctor of Law, Professor Levan Aleksidze, Deputy Minister of Justice of Georgia Giorgi Tskrialashvili, Director of the International Law Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Georgia Teimuraz Bakradze, Deputy Director of the Institute of State and Law of the Academy of Sciences of Georgia Konstantine Korkelia; witnesses  the Head of the Legal Expertise and Approval of Draft Laws Division of the Legal Department of the Parliament of Georgia Lili Begiashvili and the Head of Staff of the International Relations Committee of the Parliament of Georgia Veronica Metonidze, have considered the case - "Constitutional submission of Tbilisi Didube-Chugureti District Court". In accordance with Article 42, Clause 1 of the Organic Law "On the Constitutional Court of Georgia", the Plenum of the Court considered the case on merits in the absence of the author of the submission. Subject of the dispute  Constitutionality of Article 3 of the "Headquarters Agreement between the Republic of Georgia and the International Committee of the Red Cross" approved by the resolution of the Parliament of Georgia of October 16, 1996 with Article 42, Clause 1 and Article 82 of the Constitution of Georgia. In accordance with Article 21, Clause 1 of the Organic Law "On the Constitutional Court of Georgia", the case was admitted for consideration by the Plenum of the Constitutional Court of Georgia. The Constitutional Court of Georgia has revealed  On March 19, 2002 Tbilisi Didube-Chugureti District Court applied to the Constitutional Court of Georgia with a constitutional submission  registration   177 . The basis for filing the Constitutional Submission is Article 89, Clause 1, Sub-clause "g" of the Constitution of Georgia, Article 19, Clause 2 and Article 42 of the Organic Law "On the Constitutional Court of Georgia", Article 1, Clause 2, Article 15 and Article 16, Clauses 5-7 of the Law of Georgia "On Constitutional Legal Proceedings". According to the Constitutional Submission, Didube-Chugureti District Court is considering Shota Bitadze's claim related to his restoration at work in the International Red Cross Committee  ICRC . The author of the submission states that the respondent does not attend the court hearings and indicates to Article 3 of the "Headquarters Agreement between the Republic of Georgia and the International Committee of the Red Cross" approved by the resolution of the Parliament of Georgia of October 16, 1996, according to which the International Committee of the Red Cross enjoys immunity to any form of court and administrative activities. The author of the Constitutional Submission considers that the above mentioned norm violates not only citizen S. Bitadze's but also other Georgian citizens' constitutional rights who were employed by the Red Cross organisation. As citizens have the right to defend their labor rights in a court. According to the submission, the disputed norm contradicts Article 42 of the Constitution of Georgia stating that "Everyone has the right to apply to a court for the protection of his her rights and freedoms" and Article 82 stating that "Act of a court shall be binding for all the state bodies and persons on the whole territory of Georgia." Considering the above mentioned, the author of the Constitutional Submission requested consideration of the issue of constitutionality of Article 3 of the "Headquarters Agreement between the Republic of Georgia and the International Committee of the Red Cross" approved by the resolution of the Parliament of Georgia of October 16, 1996 with Article 42, Clause 1 and Article 82 of the Constitution of Georgia. On April 30, 2002 at the open session of the Plenum of the Constitutional Court of Georgia Lili Begiashvili and Veronica Metonidze invited to the court as witnesses explained to the court that the above mentioned Agreement was acting and valid. In the witnesses' opinion the disputed norm does not contradict the Constitution and does not violate the rights and freedoms of Georgian citizens. They indicated that the issue of legitimacy of the immunity was disputable all over the world. The immunity of the officers of the delegation of the International Committee of the Red Cross and their family members was equalized to the immunity of the officers of the diplomatic representations and their family members. Levan Aleksidze invited to the court session as a specialist stated that the relations between the local state and diplomatic establishments existing on its territory had been regulated by the international legal custom for centuries. One of the basic components of the diplomatic law is privileges and immunities of the diplomatic representations and their staff in the headquarters country. In the specialist's opinion granting privileges and immunities takes place for maximal restriction of the influence of the host country on the activities of the diplomatic establishments. In this case, when there is a dispute between a local citizen who works or worked in an embassy or an international organisation and the employer, i.e. the embassy  organisation , it is subject to the local legislation and jurisdiction. According to the specialist's conclusion, activities of the administration of the International Committee of the Red Cross, which is located in Geneva, are frequently subject to the local  Geneva  jurisdiction. The same rule is confirmed by a special internal act of the International Committee of the Red Cross Article 32 of which enumerates the cases when the immunity envisaged by the disputed norm may not be applied, in particular, "Unless otherwise specified in the Act, relations between an employer and employees shall be regulated by the local legislation." Considering the above mentioned, the specialist considers that the refusal of the administration of the International Committee of the Red Cross to attend the court hearing is groundless. In the given case it did not have the right to apply the immunity. Konstantine Korkelia invited to the court session as a specialist considers that in spite of the fact that under Article 3 of the "Headquarters Agreement between the Republic of Georgia and the International Committee of the Red Cross", the ICRC enjoys immunity to any form of court and administrative activities, this immunity does not apply to labour disputes between the Committee and its local employee. The arguments that the local employee of the Committee has the right to apply to a Georgian Court for protection of his labour right and that the International Committee of the Red Cross is obliged to attend the court hearings are confirmed by the internal regulations attached to the contract between the representative office of the Committee and its employee defining that unless otherwise envisaged relations between the Committee and its employee are regulated by the local, i.e. Georgian legislation  Article 32 of the Internal Regulations . Konstantine Korkelia considers that a Georgian court has the right to consider the said dispute, and the International Committee of the Red Cross does not have the right to apply the immunity right in this case. Teimuraz Bakradze invited to the court session as a specialist stated that the internal regulations of the international organisations regulated the issues of labour legal relations. The internal regulations of the international organisations, which contain founding documents, additional rules and norms, as well as any provisions related to the agreement, may be regarded as special constituent part of the international law as it is based on agreements, which are valid and applied on the basis of the principles of the international law. The specialist stated that the International Law recognized territorial, representative and functional immunities. The latter regulates the labour relations in the international organisations. Giorgi Tskrialashvili invited to the court session as a specialist stated that the International Committee of the Red Cross misinterpreted the disputed norm. In his opinion the stated norm does not contradict the Constitution of Georgia and Article 14 of the Agreement enables such an interpretation that immunity is not applied to the labour law. The court could have applied the analogy of law  ICRC has a similar agreement with Switzerland  and the internal regulations of the Committee, considered the case in the absence of the respondent and could have made a judgement. The said dispute is subject to the Georgian jurisdiction. After the consideration of the merits of the case on the basis of facts given in the Constitutional Submission, conclusions of the specialists invited to the sessions, witnesses' evidence, the Plenum of the Constitutional Court of Georgia has revealed the following circumstances required for making a judgement  1. The Constitutional Court of Georgia does not share the opinion given in the submission that the disputed norm violates not only citizen S. Bitadze's but also other Georgian citizens' constitutional rights who were employed by the ICRC to protect their violated labour rights in a court of general jurisdiction and that "execution of the judgements of this body will be impossible in future". In accordance with Article 1 of the "Headquarters Agreement between the Republic of Georgia and the International Committee of the Red Cross", the ICRC's status is equalized to the status of an intergovernmental international organisation. According to the conclusions of the invited specialists, the ICRC concluded agreements similar to the one with the Republic of Georgia with more than 60 countries. As Levan Aleksidze stated "The Agreement concluded between the ICRC and Georgia is similar to the agreements concluded between the ICRC and other countries, which consider it as a subject of the international law with all the relevant legal consequences, including granting diplomatic privileges and immunities to the representative offices  delegations  envisaged by the Vienna Convention On Diplomatic Relations" of 1961." Therefore, the International Committee of the Red Cross in Georgia as well as in other countries enjoys the privileges and immunities the international organisations usually enjoy. 2. According to the evidences existing in the case and the conclusions of the specialists, the ICRC as any other international organisations acquire privileges and immunity for the promotion of effective and unimpeded performance of the functions of the organisation by its representative office or the employees, considering the purposes of the organisation. For example, in accordance with Article 105 of the Charter of the United Nations Organisation  "1. The United Nations Organisation enjoys on the territory of each member state the privileges and immunities required for the achievement of its purposes. 2. Representatives of the members of the Organisation and its officials also enjoy the privileges and immunity required for the independent performance of their functions related to the activities of the Organisation." In accordance with Article 14 of the Convention "On the privileges and immunity of the United Nations Organisation" of February 13, 1946, "Granting privileges and immunity for the representatives of the members of the Organisation shall take place not for personal purposes of certain persons but for ensuring independent performance of their functions related to the activities of the Organisation". For example, in accordance with Article 14 of the above mentioned convention, a member of the organisation is obliged to waive the immunity of his representative in any case when in his opinion the immunity prevents the administration of justice. The waiver should be made without damage to the purposes of granting the immunity. Article 20 of the Convention imposes the same obligation upon the Secretary General of the United Nations Organisation. There are similar obligations in Articles 16 and 22 of the Convention "On special institutions and immunity made by the General Assembly of the United Nations Organisation on November 21, 1947. Considering the above mentioned, the immunity granted to the international organisations including the one granted to the ICRC, is not absolute, its scope and limits are aimed at promotion of performance of the organization's functions. Consequently, the immunity does not apply to the activities and disputes, which are beyond the purposes and functions of the organisation, such as labour disputes between the administration of the international organisation and its employees. The above mentioned was confirmed by all the invited specialists. According to Konstantine Korkelia's conclusion "The International Committee of the Red Cross enjoys the immunity from the Georgian Government but not in relation to labour disputes, which may arise between the representative office of the ICRC and its employee". Levan Aleksidze indicated that similar disputes were subject to local legislation and jurisdiction. In his opinion "The world legal practice is going in this direction. The practice of the international organisations is going in this way too." Both the specialists brought as an example the agreement between the ICRC and Switzerland Government, Article 5 of which regulates the immunity of the ICRC and directly indicates that the immunity does not apply to labour disputes between the ICRC and its current or former employee  Article 5, Clause 1, Sub-clause c . Considering the above mentioned, if an employee of the ICRC files a claim related to a labour dispute with the Swiss court, the latter will be authorised to consider the stated dispute. Consequently, the ICRC cannot apply the immunity for rejection to attend the local court session. According to the evidences existing in the case, unlike the Switzerland, a similar norm has not been envisaged by the most of the agreements made by the ICRC and other countries. However, in spite of the absence of such indication, considering the purpose of granting immunity to an international organization, the immunity of the ICRC does not apply to labour disputes arising in this organisation itself in any headquarters country. The above mentioned is confirmed by the internal regulations attached to the contract between the representative office of the Committee and its employee, Article 32 of which defines that "Unless otherwise envisaged, relations between the Committee and its employee are regulated by the local legislation". In this regard, the Constitutional Court shares the following opinion of the specialist Konstantine Korkelia invited to the case that  "Due to the fact that in relation to labour disputes the Agreement does not stipulate other applicable legislation  for example, Swiss legislation , it is clear that in each particular case related to labour disputes the rule envisaged by the Georgian legislation should be applied". The Constitutional Court considers that in spite of the fact that in accordance with Article 3 of the "Headquarters Agreement between the Republic of Georgia and the International Committee of the Red Cross", the ICRC, its property and assets enjoyed immunity to any form of court and administrative activities, this did not imply an absolute immunity of the ICRC. The immunity does not apply to labour disputes between ICRC and its local employees that means that  1  a local employee of the ICRC has the right to apply to a local court for protection of his her violated labour rights; 2  The Georgian courts are authorised to consider the above mentioned disputes; 3  The ICRC does not have the right to apply its immunity and to neglect the court hearings. Thus, the disputed norm does not imply the court immunity of the ICRC in relation to labour disputes and therefore, it does not restrict S. Bitadze's constitutional right and the constitutional right of other citizens employed by the ICRC to appeal to a court. The norm did not exclude the imperative nature of the relevant acts for the ICRC either. Therefore, the disputed norm does not imply the judicial immunity on labour disputes of the ICRC and does not restrict the constitutional right of applying to a court of citizen S. Bitadze and other persons employed by the ICRC. Non-compliance of Article 3 of the "Headquarters Agreement between the Republic of Georgia and the International Committee of the Red Cross" approved by the resolution of the Parliament of Georgia of October 16, 1996 with Article 42, Clause 1 and Article 82 of the Constitution of Georgia shall not be confirmed. 2. The Judgement shall come into force from the moment of its public declaration at the sitting of the Constitutional Court. 3. The Judgement shall be final and not subject to appeal or review. 4. Copies of the present Judgement shall be sent to Tbilisi Didube-Chugureti District Court, the President of Georgia, the Parliament of Georgia and the Supreme Court of Georgia. 5. The Decision shall be promulgated in the official gazette within 7 days. sections.full_text: Identification  GBR-2001-1-005 Identification  GBR-2001-1-005  2001  UKHL 23 09.05.2001 House of Lords Session 2000-01 Publications on the Internet Judgments Judgments - Alconbury HOUSE OF LORDS Lord Slynn of Hadley Lord Nolan Lord Hoffmann Lord Hutton Lord Clyde OPINIONS OF THE LORDS OF APPEAL FOR JUDGMENT IN THE CAUSE REGINA v SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE ENVIRONMENT, TRANSPORT AND THE REGIONS  ORIGINAL APPELLANT AND CROSS-RESPONDENT  EX PARTE HOLDING AND BARNES PLC  ORIGINAL RESPONDENTS AND CROSS-APPELLANTS   ON APPEAL FROM THE QUEEN'S BENCH DIVISION OF THE HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE  REGINA v SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE ENVIRONMENT, TRANSPORT AND THE REGIONS  ORIGINAL APPELLANT AND CROSS-RESPONDENT  EX PARTE ALCONBURY DEVELOPMENTS LIMITED AND OTHERS  RESPONDENTS  AND OTHERS  CROSS-APPELLANTS   ON APPEAL FROM THE QUEEN'S BENCH DIVISION OF THE HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE  REGINA v SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE ENVIRONMENT, TRANSPORT AND THE REGIONS  APPELLANT  EX PARTE LEGAL   GENERAL ASSURANCE SOCIETY LIMITED  ON APPEAL FROM THE QUEEN'S BENCH DIVISION OF THE HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE   CONJOINED APPEALS  ON 9 MAY 2001  2001  UKHL 23 LORD SLYNN OF HADLEY My Lords, 1. These three appeals come direct to the House pursuant to section 12 of the Administration of Justice Act 1969 from decisions of the Divisional Court  Tuckey LJ and Harrison J  in a judgment given on 13 December 2000. Although there are differences between the three cases they raise broadly the same question as to whether certain decision making processes of the Secretary of State for the Environment, Transport and the Regions  "the Secretary of State"  are compatible with article 6 1  of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms  1953   Cmd 8969  as incorporated in the Human Rights Act 1998  "the 1998 Act" . There was a consequential question as to whether if these processes are not compatible there should be a declaration under section 4 of the 1998 Act. 2. The Divisional Court held that the following statutory provisions were incompatible with article 6 and accordingly made a declaration of incompatibility under section 4 of the 1998 Act   a  The Town and Country Planning Act 1990  i  section 77;  ii  section 78 and 79  excluding the words inserted into sub section 79 4  by paragraph 19 of Schedule 7 to the Planning and Compensation Act 1991 ;  iii  paragraphs 3 and 4 of Schedule 6  insofar as it applied to section 79 ;  b  The Transport and Works Act 1992 sections 1, 3 and 23 4 ;  c  The Highways Act 1980 sections 14 3  a , 16 5  a , 18 3  a  and 125 and paragraphs 1, 7 and 8 of Part 1 of Schedule 1;  d  The Acquisition of Land Act 1981 section 2  3  and paragraph 4 of Schedule 1. 3. The Secretary of State appeals against all these decisions and declarations. Since a related question had arisen in Scotland in County Properties Ltd v The Scottish Ministers 2000 SLT 965, the Lord Advocate has intervened in support of the application that the decision of the Divisional Court be reversed on the basis that article 6 1  does not apply to the decision making processes under review and on the basis that they are not in any event incompatible with a Convention right. The role of other parties to the proceedings will appear in a brief summary of facts to which I turn. I summarise briefly because the facts are more fully set out in the judgment of the Divisional Court to which reference can be made and which it is not helpful to repeat 4. Alconbury Developments Ltd  "AD"  has agreed with the Ministry of Defence, the owner of a disused airfield at Alconbury, that if planning permission is given AD will redevelop the site into a national distribution centre in return for financial payments to the Ministry. AD applied to Huntingdon District Council  "HDC"  for planning permission for the overall scheme with adjunct facilities and approach road and rail sidings. It also applied under various individual applications for planning permission for parts of the scheme. There were related applications  1  to Cambridge County Council  "CCC"  as the waste disposal authority for planning permission to construct a temporary recycling depot on part of the site;  2  to HDC for permission to set up a commercial air freight operation though this was opposed by a group of local residents  "Huntsnap"  and the application was withdrawn in March 1998;  3  to the Secretary of State under section 1 of the Transport and Works Act for permission to build a rail connection between the airfield and the east coast rail line together with railway sidings within the airfield. 5. On 4 August 1998 the Secretary of State refused a request to call in the planning application to be determined by him but after the HDC dismissed the overall application for planning permission and the CCC failed to determine the application for the waste recycling depot within the prescribed period, AD's appeals were "recovered" by the Secretary of State for determination by him under paragraph 3 of Schedule 6 to the Town and Country Planning Act rather than by an inspector appointed by the Secretary of State. This was done on the basis that "the appeals relate to proposals for development of major importance, having more than local significance". 6. An inspector was appointed to hold an inquiry at which for various reasons Huntsnap and an association of Nene Valley residents  "NVA"  together with English Nature, a statutory body, appeared. Huntsnap and NVA contended that the proceedings were contrary to article 6. AD accordingly applied for judicial review of the Secretary of State's decision in order to clarify the position, contending that the Secretary of State's decisions to take jurisdiction over the planning appeals and the TWA applications were lawful. CCC supported AD; HDC Huntsnap and NVA opposed it On the present appeal AD and CCC support the Secretary of State. HDC and NVA contend that the Divisional Court were right in holding that there was a breach of section 6 1  but wrong in its decision on section 6 2 . The Secretary of State was bound to act so as to avoid incompatibility with the Convention and therefore to permit the appeal to be determined by an independent inspector. 7. Holding   Barnes Plc  "HB"  applied for planning permission to use land at Canvey Island for the storage and sale of damaged cars. The Health   Safety Executive objected because the development was near to gas storage on some neighbouring sites but the executive was willing to reconsider the position if modifications to the proposal could be made. The local planning authority on 2 May 2000 resolved that it was minded to grant permission. On 25 July 2000 the Secretary of State directed, pursuant to section 77 of the Town   Country Planning Act that the application should be referred to him because of  a  the nature of the proposed use,  b  the impact it could have on the future economic prosperity of Canvey Island and  c  the site's location close to hazardous installations. It is that direction which HB challenged on an application for judicial review. 8. Legal   General Assurance Society Ltd. These proceedings are brought by the Secretary of State at the invitation of Legal   General Assurance Society Ltd  "L   G" . The issue relates to an improvement scheme at junction 13 of the A34 M4 proposed by the Secretary of State through the Highway Authority. There are complex details of a dual two-lane carriageway all-purpose road, 100 metres to the west of the existing junction 13, together with connected slip and side roads. In August 1993 following an inquiry, orders were confirmed for the work to go ahead. The court quashed part of one of the side road orders and new draft orders were published on 17 February 2000 followed by a draft compulsory purchase order on 24 February 2000. Following objections the Secretary of State appointed an inspector to hold a public inquiry into the draft order. L   G which own some land the subject of the draft compulsory purchase order invited the Secretary of State to seek a ruling of the court as to the compatibility of the proceedings with the Convention. L   G decided not to be represented in the proceedings and the Attorney General appointed counsel as amici curiae in that case both before the Divisional Court and before the House. 9. The Divisional Court set out with clarity the details of the legislation relevant to these cases. I gratefully adopt their account in paragraphs 30 to 52 of the judgment and accordingly I only summarise the essential characteristics with which these appeals are concerned. 10. It is important to make clear that these appeals are not concerned directly with issues which affect the vast majority of applications for planning permission. Those applications are dealt with by elected local authorities and not by the Secretary of State even though local authorities have to take into account the development plan for their area which does reflect national policies, guidance and instructions given by the Secretary of State. Nor are the present appeals concerned with the majority of appeals from such local authority decisions which are decided by inspectors on the Secretary of State's behalf even though those inspectors may be full-time officials of the Planning Inspectorate and even though they must have regard to the Secretary of States's policies and the framework document setting out their functions. The present appeals under the Town and Country Planning Act are concerned only with applications which are "called in" by the Secretary of State under section 77 of the Act and those appeals which are "recovered" by the Secretary of State under paragraph 3 of Schedule 6 to the Act. The Divisional Court found that of some 500,000 planning applications each year about 130 were "called in" by the Secretary of State and of some 13,000 appeals to the Secretary of State each year about 100 were "recovered" by the Secretary of State. In both types of case the Secretary of State followed to a large extent the recommendations of the inspectors. These figures of 130 and 100 are not insignificant and they concern important questions, important both to the individual and to the nation, but the figures do show the limits of the question raised on the appeals. 11. It is therefore important to see what are the statutory powers under these various sections. 12. Under section 77 of the TCPA the Secretary of State may  1  give directions requiring applications for planning permission to be referred to him instead of being dealt with by local planning authorities  " 5  Before determining an application referred to him under this section, the Secretary of State shall, if either the applicant or the local planning authority wish, give each of them an opportunity of appearing before, and being heard by, a person appointed by the Secretary of State for the purpose." 13. By the Town and Country Planning  Inquiries Procedure   England  Rules 2000  SI 2000 1624  the applicant and the local planning authority are entitled to appear before the inspector  "the person appointed"  to call and cross examine witnesses and to make representations. 14. Section 78 of the Town and Country Planning Act provides for an applicant who has been refused planning permission or granted planning permission subject to conditions to appeal to the Secretary of State. Before determining an appeal, the Secretary of State is required by section 79 2 , if the appellant or the local planning authority wish, to give them an opportunity to be heard by a person appointed by the Secretary of State. By paragraph 1 of Schedule 6 to the Act, the Secretary of State may prescribe classes of appeals to be determined by appointed persons rather than by the Secretary of State. By paragraph 3 1  of Schedule 6 the Secretary of State "may, if he thinks fit, direct that an appeal which would otherwise fall to be determined by an appointed person shall instead be determined by the Secretary of State". Such direction shall state the reasons for which it is given and it is to be served on the appellant, the local planning authority and any person who has made representations. 15. The Town and Country Planning  Inquiries Procedure   England  Rules 2000 which replaced the Town and Country Planning Act  Inquiries Procedure  Rules 1992  SI 1992 2039  with effect from 1 August 2000, apply to any local inquiry ordered by the Secretary of State before he determines an application for planning permission referred to him under section 77 or an appeal to him under section 78 of the Act. 16. When an inspector is holding an inquiry leading to an appeal which he will determine himself or when he is holding an inquiry before the Secretary of State decides an application for planning permission called in by him under section 77, or before the Secretary of State determines an appeal under section 78 "recovered" by him, the procedures are broadly the same until the inspector's final report. When an inspector takes a decision he must set out that decision with reasons and notify the parties. When, however, he is holding an inquiry before the Secretary of State takes a decision he must state his conclusions and make his recommendations. There is an important provision in rule 17  5  of the Town and Country Planning  Inquiries Procedure   England  Rules 2000 - " 5  If, after the close of an inquiry, the Secretary of State-  a  differs from the inspector on any matter of fact mentioned in, or appearing to him to be material to, a conclusion reached by the inspector; or  b  takes into consideration any new evidence or new matter of fact  not being a matter of government policy , "and is for that reason disposed to disagree with a recommendation made by the inspector, he shall not come to a decision which is at variance with that recommendation without first notifying the persons entitled to appear at the inquiry who appeared at it of his disagreement and the reasons for it  and affording them an opportunity of making written representations to him or  if the Secretary of State has taken into consideration any new evidence or new matter of fact, not being a matter of government policy  of asking for the re-opening of the inquiry. . . . " 7  The Secretary of State may, as he thinks fit, cause an inquiry to be re-opened, and he shall do so if asked by the applicant or the local planning authority in the circumstances mentioned in paragraph  5  and within the period mentioned in paragraph  6 ; and where an inquiry is re-opened  whether by the same or a different inspector -  a  the Secretary of State shall send to the persons entitled to appear at the inquiry who appeared at it a written statement of the matters with respect to which further evidence is invited; and  b  paragraphs  3  to  8  of rule 10 shall apply as if the references to an inquiry were references to a re-opened inquiry." 17. In relation to applications made under the Transport   Works Act 1992 in relation to the construction and operation of a railway and to authorise the compulsory acquisition of land and to grant any necessary planning permission, under the Transport and Works Act, the decision is taken by the Secretary of State. Where an objection is received, a public inquiry must be held if the objector wishes. The provisions of the Transport and Works  Inquiries Procedure  Rules 1992  SI 1992 2817  are broadly similar to those found in the Town and Country Planning  Inquiries Procedure   England  Rules 2000. 18. The Highways Act 1980 gives to the Secretary of State power to make orders in relation to existing and proposed highways and to empower the highway authorities for trunk roads to stop up or improve highways in prescribed circumstances. If a local inquiry is held, the inspector appointed reports his conclusions and recommendations to the Secretary of State. The Highways  Inquiries Procedure  Rules 1994  SI 1994 3263  contain similar provision to those in the Town and Country Planning  Inquiries Procedure   England  Rules 2000. The Secretary of State may make an order with or without modification but if he disagrees with his inspector's conclusions or recommendations the Secretary of State must follow a procedure similar to that in rule 17 5  of the Town and Country Planning  Inquiries Procedure   England  Rules 2000  see rule 26 4  of the Highways  Inquiries Procedure  Rules 1994. When exercising his powers under the Highways Act, the Secretary of State is given power to acquire land compulsorily. The Acquisition of Land Act 1981 and the Compulsory Purchase by Ministers  Inquiries Procedure  Rules 1994  SI 1994 3264  provide for a public local inquiry to be held if an objection is received. The inspector makes his conclusions and recommendations to the Secretary of State. If the latter disagrees he is required once again to follow a procedure similar to that in rule 17 5  of the Town and Country Planning  Inquiries Procedure   England  Rules 2000. 19. The various statutes provide for judicial review rather than for an appeal on the facts or the merits of the decision. Thus in section 288 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 "288. Proceedings for questioning the validity of other orders, decisions and directions  1  If any person-  a  is aggrieved by any order to which this section applies and wishes to question the validity of that order on the grounds-  i  that the order is not within the powers of this Act, or  ii  that any of the relevant requirements have not been complied with in relation to that order; or  b  is aggrieved by any action on the part of the Secretary of State to which this section applies and wishes to question the validity of that action on the grounds-  i  that the action is not within the powers of this Act, or  ii  that any of the relevant requirements have not been complied with in relation to that action, he may make an application to the High Court under this section." 20. Section 22 of the Transport and Works Act 1992, the provisions for challenge set out in paragraph 2 of Schedule 2 to the Highways Act 1980 and section 23 of the Acquisition of Land Act 1981 are similar. 21. The essence of the complaints in all these cases is that there is a violation of article 6 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights incorporated in Schedule 1 to the Human Rights Act 1998. Article 6 provides as follows "Right to a Fair Trial 1. In the determination of his civil rights and obligations or of any criminal charge against him, everyone is entitled to a fair and public hearing within a reasonable time by an independent and impartial tribunal established by law. . . ". 22. The second and third paragraphs of the article are concerned with criminal offences and are not relevant to the present appeal. 23. The contention in these proceedings is that the processes which I have set out, violate article 6. These are civil rights which are determined without a fair and public hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal established by law. 24. There is really no complaint about the inquiry conducted by an inspector or about the safeguards laid down for evidence to be called and challenged and for representations and objections to be heard. It is not suggested that the inspector himself is not independent and impartial even though he is a member of eg the Planning Inspectorate in the case of planning appeals. The essential complaint is that when a decision is taken, not by such an inspector but by the Secretary of State or one of the Ministers of State or an Under Secretary on behalf of the Secretary of State there is such an interest in the decision that the person concerned cannot be regarded as an independent and impartial tribunal. The Secretary of State or his department, it is said, lays down policy and directs what he or the department considers to be the most efficient and effective use of land in what he sees to be the public interest. They issue guidance and framework directions which local authorities, inspectors and officials operating the planning system must follow. All of these are bound to affect the mind of the Secretary of State when he takes decisions on called in applications or on appeals which he recovers, it is alleged. Moreover it is said that in the case of Alconbury there is a particular factor in that the land in question is owned by another Government department, the Ministry of Defence. 25. Mr Kingston. on behalf of HDC also criticised the correspondence and minutes relevant to the Alconbury project. He contends that the role of the officials involved at the Planning and Transport Division in the Government Office for the Region  "GO"  was such that there was a real connection not only with planning matters and planning ministers but also with transport ministers and officials and their policies. A site visit by the Parliamentary Under-Secretary for Transport may not have been prejudicial to the determination of the application before the matter was taken over by the Secretary of State. It was quite different once he took over the case for his own decision. As it was put in the case, even leaving aside the fact that the Secretary of State was carrying out his own policy "it is quite clear that the structures in place in relation to cases where the Secretary of State has recovered jurisdiction do not preserve any appearance of independence". 26. Your Lordships have been referred to many decisions of the European Court of Human Rights on article 6 of the Convention. Although the Human Rights Act 1998 does not provide that a national court is bound by these decisions it is obliged to take account of them so far as they are relevant. In the absence of some special circumstances it seems to me that the court should follow any clear and constant jurisprudence of the European Court of Human Rights. If it does not do so there is at least a possibility that the case will go to that court which is likely in the ordinary case to follow its own constant jurisprudence. 27. It is not necessary to refer to all these cases but some statements of principle by the European Court of Human Rights are important in guiding the House in the present decisions. A preliminary question has arisen as to whether a dispute over administrative law matters of the present kind involved the determination of "civil rights". At first sight to a common lawyer there appears a difference and that difference might seem stronger to a lawyer in a civil law country. In Ringeisen v Austria  No 1   1971  1 EHRR 455, para 94, however, the court said "For article 6 1  to be applicable to a case  'contestation'  it is not necessary that both parties to the proceedings should be private persons, which is the view of the majority of the Commission and of the Government. The wording of article 6 1  is far wider; the French expression 'contestations sur  des  droits et obligations de caractère civil' covers all proceedings the result of which is decisive for private rights and obligations. The English text, 'determination of . . . civil rights and obligations', confirms this interpretation. "The character of the legislation which governs how the matter is to be determined  civil, commercial, administrative law, etc  and that of the authority which is invested with jurisdiction in the matter  ordinary court, administrative body, etc  are therefore of little consequence." See also Kaplan v United Kingdom  1980  4 EHRR 64, 85, Allan Jacobsson v Sweden  1989  12 EHRR 56. 28. In Fredin v Sweden  1991  13 EHRR 784, the court accepted that disputes under planning rules could affect civil rights to build on the applicant's land. Despite the submissions of the Lord Advocate that a decision on a called in application is not a "contestation" on the basis of these and a number of other cases it seems to me plain that this dispute is one which involves the determination of "civil rights" within the meaning of the Convention. 29. The European Court of Human Rights has, however, recognised from the beginning that some administrative law decisions which affect civil rights are taken by ministers answerable to elected bodies. Where there is a two stage process ie there is such an administrative decision which is subject to review by a court, there is a constant line of authority of the European court that regard has to be paid to both stages of the process. Thus even where "jurisdictional organs of professional associations" are set up  "Nonetheless, in such circumstances the Convention calls at least for one of the two following systems  either the jurisdictional organs themselves comply with the requirements of article 6 1 , or they do not so comply but are subject to subsequent control by a judicial body which has full jurisdiction and does provide the guarantees of article 6 1 ."  Albert and Le Compte v Belgium  1983  5 EHRR 533, para 29 . See also Le Compte, Van Leuven and De Meyere v Belgium  1981  4 EHRR 1, Golder v The United Kingdon  1975  1 EHRR 524. 30. In Kaplan v United Kingdom 4 EHRR 64, the Commission noted, at paragraph 150, that  "it is a feature of the administrative law of all the contracting states that in numerous different fields public authorities are empowered by law to take various forms of action impinging on the private rights of citizens." The Commission referred to its earlier opinion in Ringeisen v Austria  No 1  where having referred to a number of examples of State regulation the Commission had stated  "These examples, to which numerous others could be added, seem to indicate that it is a normal feature of contemporary administrative law that the rights and obligations of the citizen, even in matters which relate very closely to his private property or his private activities, are determined by some public authority which does not fulfil the conditions laid down in article 6 1  with respect to independent and impartial tribunals." 31. The Commission continued, at paragraph 159, in relation to judicial review  "It is also a common feature of their administrative law, and indeed almost a corollary of the grant of discretionary powers, that the scope of judicial review of the relevant decisions is limited." And at paragraph 161  "An interpretation of article 6 1  under which it was held to provide a right to a full appeal on the merits of every administrative decision affecting private rights would therefore lead to a result which was inconsistent with the existing, and long-standing, legal position in most of the contracting states." 32. In ISKCON v United Kingdom Application No 20490 92, 8 March 1994  a decision of the Commission  a local authority served an enforcement notice on ISKCON alleging a material change of use of the land. ISKCON appealed against the notice under section 174 2  of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 and after a report by an inspector the Secretary of State largely confirmed the enforcement notice. The High Court and the Court of Appeal rejected ISKCON'S appeal. On a complaint under the Convention the Commission recalled that an appeal under section 289 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 lay only on a point of law but it took into account that the local authority could only take proceedings within the limits of section 174 of that Act and that in accordance with its own structure plans and the policy guidance laid down by the Secretary of State ISKCON could then seek a determination as to whether the legal requirements had been met. The Commission concluded "The Commission recalls that the High Court dealt with each of ISKCON'S grounds of appeal on its merits, point by point, without ever having to decline jurisdiction. Moreover, it was open to ISKCON to contend in the High Court that findings of fact by the inspector and or the Secretary of State were unsupported by evidence, as they could have argued that the administrative authorities failed to take into account an actual fact or did take into account an immaterial fact. Finally, the High Court could have interfered with the administrative authorities' decisions if those decisions had been irrational having regard to the facts established by the authorities.
